The Notes will mature on,       , 2029. The Issuer will pay interest on the outstanding principal amount of the Notes at a per annum rate equal to three-month
EURIBOR (subject to a 0% floor) plus %, reset quarterly. Interest will be paid on the Notes quarterly in arrears on

each       ,       ,        and       , commencing on      , 2024. At any time on or after       , 2025, the Issuer may, at its option, redeem all
or a portion of the Notes at par. At any time prior to       , 2025, the Issuer may, at its option, redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal
to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date, plus the applicable
“make whole” premium as described in this offering memorandum (this “Offering Memorandum”). Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change
of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus
accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to but excluding the date of purchase. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have
occurred if the Issuer’s consolidated net leverage ratio is less than certain specified levels at the time of such event. See “Description of the Notes.” In addition,
the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes upon the occurrence of certain changes in applicable tax law.

The Notes will be the Issuer’s general, senior obligations and will rank pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of the Issuer that
are not expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including obligations under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (as defined herein), certain
cash management obligations (including supply chain financing), if any, and certain hedging obligations and rank senior in right of payment to any existing and
future obligations of the Issuer that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, if any. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis (the
“Note Guarantees” and each, a “Note Guarantee”) by certain subsidiaries of the Issuer (each a “Guarantor” and together, the “Guarantors”). The Note
Guarantee issued by each Guarantor will rank _pari passu in right of payment with any existing and future obligations of that Guarantor that are not expressly_
subordinated in right of payment to such Note Guarantee (including indebtedness incurred under the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations)
and rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future obligations of such Guarantor that are expressly subordinated in right of payment to such Note
Guarantee, if any.

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains non-IFRS financial measures and ratios, including EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA Before Run Rate Cost Synergies, Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate
Cost Synergies Margin, Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Capital Expenditure, Operating Net Working
Capital, Operating Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion Before Run Rate Cost Synergies and certain leverage and
coverage ratios, among others, that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS. Our non-IFRS
financial measures are defined by us as set out below.

We define “EBITDA” as net income/(net loss) for the period before income taxes, financial income, financial
expenses, depreciation, amortization and impairment losses and the reversal of impairment losses, each as shown
in the Consolidated Financial Statements.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate Cost Synergies” as EBITDA adjusted for exceptional items
as described under “Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Data”, before
run-rate cost synergies arising from fulfilment center network expansion.

We define “Run Rate **Adjusted EBITDA” as EBITDA adjusted for exceptional items as described under**
“Summary Consolidated Financial and Other Information—Other Financial Data” and run-rate cost synergies
arising from the fulfillment center network expansion.

We define “Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate Cost Synergies Margin” as Adjusted EBITDA Before Run
Rate Cost Synergies divided by revenue.

We define “Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA Margin” as Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue.

We define “Capital Expenditure” as the sum of: (i) purchase of property, plant and equipment, (ii) purchase of
intangible assets and (iii) capitalized development costs each as shown in the consolidated statements of cash
flows in the Consolidated Financial Statements.

We define “Operating **Net Working Capital” as the sum of (i) inventories and prepayments for inventories,**
(ii) trade and other receivables, (iii) trade and other payables and (iv) others. ‘Others’ includes refund liabilities
and assets for the right to recover possession of goods for expected returns as well as liabilities in connection with
its supply chain financing.

We define “Operating Free Cash Flow” as EBITDA plus the changes in net foreign exchange differences,
increase/decrease in other liabilities and provisions, decrease/increase in other assets, decrease/increase in trade

i


-----

and other receivables, decrease/increase in inventories and similar assets, increase/decrease in trade payables and
other liabilities each as shown in net cash flows from operating activities (changes in current assets, non-current
financial assets, current and non-current liabilities included in net cash flows from operating activities), minus
payment of lease liabilities as shown in net cash flows from financing activities and minus Capital Expenditure.

We define “Cash Conversion **Before Run Rate Cost Synergies” as the ratio between Operating Free Cash Flow**
and Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate Cost Synergies.

There is no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as non-recurring will not recur in the future or
that similar items will not be incurred in the future.

For a reconciliation of our net income/net loss for the period to EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate
Cost Synergies and Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA as well as a reconciliation of Operating Free Cash Flow and
Cash Conversion Before Run Rate Cost Synergies, see “Summary Consolidated Financial and Other
_Information.” For a reconciliation and description of Capital Expenditure and Operating Net Working Capital, see_
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.”

**SUMMARY**

**Overview**

We are one of Europe’s leading online destinations for premium and luxury off-price fashion. With a focus on
international premium and luxury brands, we offer our customers in 27 countries across Europe a standing
assortment of highly desirable fashion at exclusive prices in a premium shopping environment. At the same time,
we enable our brand partners to clear overstock at scale with minimum visibility and strong brand equity
protection. The success of our unique business model is based on its closed character with an invitation-only
customer membership, viral customer growth leading to unparalleled marketing efficiency, longstanding brand
partner and customer relationships, a tech-focused mindset, and its inherent contribution to more sustainability in
the fashion industry. We have a strong track record of profitable growth over many years. For the years ended
December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated revenue of €942.9
million, €1,051.0 million, €1,226.0 million and €1,290.6 million, respectively, an Adjusted EBITDA Before Run
Rate Cost Synergies of €138.7 million, €132.5 million, €165.8 million and €183.0 million, respectively, and an
Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate Cost Synergies Margin of 14.7%, 12.6%, 13.5% and 14.2%, respectively.
Our revenue and Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA grew from €1,077.8 million and €143.6 million, respectively, in
the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 to €1,290.6 million and €200.9 million in the twelve months ended
March 31, 2024, representing increases over 20% and 40%, respectively, over the same period. Our online revenue
accounted for 93.0%, 91.2%, 91.9% and 92.1% of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022
and 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, respectively (with a CAGR of 13.3% from the year ended
December 31, 2021 to the year ended December 31, 2023). While 59.0% of our revenue for the twelve months
ended March 31, 2024 (€762.0 million) was generated in Germany, our international business outside of Germany
continues to gain importance relative to our Germany business and experienced strong revenue growth from
€384.3 million (35.7% of revenue) in the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 to €528.5 million (41% of revenue)
in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, and from €267.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to
€489.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, representing a CAGR of 35.2% over the same period.

**Strengths**

We believe that our business is characterized by a number of key strengths that set it apart from our competitors:

**_A European Leader in the Most Attractive, Resilient and Fastest Growing Fashion Segment_**

We focus on the fastest growing segment of the off-price fashion market, the online off-price fashion market, with
a European market size estimated at approximately €20 billion and projected to grow at a 10% CAGR through
2028, reaching approximately €31 billion (excluding the U.K., Turkey and Russia). Additionally, we also
participate in the offline off-price market (which has a European market size estimated at approximately €29
billion excluding the U.K., Turkey and Russia) through our four retail stores, two of which are located in Munich,
one in Vienna and one in Dresden. The total European off-price fashion market (comprised of the aforementioned
online and offline) has a size estimated at approximately €49 billion and is projected to grow at over a 6% CAGR
through 2028, reaching approximately €64 billion (excluding the U.K., Turkey and Russia). Expansion in the
online off-price sector is mainly driven by three decisive market growth levers: a) growth in the overall size of
the European mid-to-luxury fashion market, which is anticipated to increase from €247 billion in 2023 to €293
billion in 2028, b) the expected growth of the off-price share in the European mid-market-to-luxury fashion
market, with penetration expected to increase from 20% in 2023 to 22% in 2028, and, most importantly, c) the
online penetration growth in the European off-price fashion market, which is expected to grow from 41% in 2023
to 49% in 2028. In addition to its growth potential, the off-price fashion market is characterized by its resilience
to the economic cycles due to premium and luxury consumers’ continued interest in finding good deals in fashion
across all economic environments, coupled with the difficulty for brands to accurately predict demand and an
overall incentive to over-produce. As a result, while consumer spend tends to decrease in the overall fashion
market in the context of economic downturns, the off-price fashion market thrives in recessions due to the
consumer spend shift to lower purchase prices available in the off-price fashion market. On the other hand, during
periods of strong overall fashion market performance, the off-price fashion market still shows robust growth
supported by overall market buoyancy. The following table compares the growth development of the overall
European fashion market to that of the off-price fashion submarket across several market downturns:

We are a leading premium and luxury player in the European online off-price fashion market due to our strong
positioning in Germany as well as internationally. Furthermore, we are the only off-price fashion player with an
exclusive, invitation-only membership model. In 2021, our management decided to shift our strategy towards
accelerating our international growth in order to take advantage of the consolidation trend in the European online
off-price fashion market. This trend is illustrated by the growth in the share of the market captured by the top five
mid-to-luxury players, which has evolved from comprising 25% to 35% of the market in 2018 to comprising 30
to 40% of such market in 2023. This consolidation trend is still ongoing and is expected to continue evolving,
with a leading international strategy consultancy firm estimating that these players will capture 35% to 45% of
the market by 2028.

**_Superior Value Proposition Towards Brands and Customers, Resulting in a Brand and NMV Retention of_**
**_Approximately 100%_**

Our success is based on our deep and long-standing relationships with our brand partners and our customers. We
continue to grow our business alongside our top brands, having achieved double-digit growth across our top brand
tiers and more than doubled the NMV of our top 50 brands from 2019 to 2023. During the same period, we have
also realized a brand relationship retention rate of almost 100%. This achievement is based on our strong value
proposition towards brands, which are able to clear overstock at scale in a desirable environment with strong brand
equity protection. This results from a combination of a) the exclusivity of our platform (we have a members-only,
invitation-only model and periodically sift out inactive members to keep an engaged customer base), b) our ability
to block display of our brands’ off-price offerings outside of the closed membership base (with no Google listings
and no crawling through external websites and almost 100% of our products being sold in our own ecosystem)
and c) our ability to block access to our platform by deal platforms and the use of invalid invitation codes (for
example, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we block over one million of such non-member website
visit attempts per year. Our good relationships with our brand partners mean we are the “first call” for many of
our brand partners, resulting in access to large volumes of attractive overstock. We continue to work on making
our product selection attractive and recently implemented our elevation strategy (“Elevation Strategy”) pursuant
to which we seek to advance our value proposition and focus on highly desirable brands, resulting in higher appeal
for brand partners (which in turn enables the acquisition of additional luxury brand partners) and customers,
ultimately delivering higher profitability for BestSecret. As a result of our strategy, the proportion of our online
NMV in the “highly desirable” brand segment increased significantly between 2019 and 2023 as illustrated by the
following table:

Our customers find us attractive for a host of reasons encompassing, among others, our superior brand portfolio,
our high-end environment, and our exclusive prices, which in our view combines the best aspects of both off-price
and full-price fashion: while we have a leading position with respect to the assortment of luxury brands compared
to our off-price peers (source: market report from international leading strategy consultancy firm, 2024) and our
standing assortment is ten-fold that of flash sales players, we offer 20% to 80% discounts on our items,
representing an approximately 30% price advantage when compared against the prices of full-price retailers. At
the same time, we maintain a full-price alike onsite experience, delivery times and customer service. Our Elevation
Strategy and the continuous advancement of our value proposition and focus on highly desirable brands further
increase the appeal of our platform to our customers. The success of our strategies can be evidenced by our online
customer growth between 2019 and 2024, which grew at a CAGR of over 20% with an average CSR of over 2%
(excluding the 2021 average, in which marketing spend was intentionally increased beyond 2%). In terms of yearon-year growth, the total number of active customers in 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022 and 2023 grew by 28%, 21%,
58%, 14% and 16% from the prior year, respectively.

**_Unique Viral Growth Engine, Resulting in Unparalleled Marketing Efficiency_**

At the heart of our highly successful and unique business model is our viral customer growth model. Active
customers invite friends and family members, who then register on our platform and eventually become active
customers upon carrying out their first order. This ensures exponential customer growth at a minimal cost. We
have also implemented a complementary paid growth model pursuant to which we invite non-viral customers via
direct, one-on-one marketing efforts. We leverage this paid customer acquisition model to accelerate our customer
growth by planting new customer “seeds” in underpenetrated regions in Germany and our international markets.
While we only opportunistically invested into paid growth before 2021, we now systematically use targeted
performance marketing to pursue international growth. Nevertheless, viral growth remains our principal source of
new customers. Viral customers have historically accounted for the vast majority of our new customers and
continue to do so, with approximately 76% of our new customers in 2023 being viral new customers, despite our
customer inflow having more than doubled since 2019. Furthermore, although customers tend to invite most
during their first year as a member, resulting in higher viral rates (defined as the number of new online viral
customers in the last twelve months divided by the average number of active online customers in the last twelve
months), for markets with a high share of new customers, our viral growth remains strong after the first year across
the markets in which we operate, including our core market, Germany, where we have a viral rate of 22% despite
the market’s higher maturity. In our International markets, we have a viral rate of 38%.

3


-----

Consistent viral customer generation in turn ensures high LTV to CAC ratios, with LTV defined as cumulative
PCII (gross margin minus fulfillment costs, including payments and customer care) per online customer since first
order, and CAC defined as total marketing expenses divided by total number of new customers, resulting in
approximately 20% customer growth despite low marketing investment. The following graph reflects the
LTV/CAC ratio for the 2019 and 2023 period and demonstrates that we are able to maintain short payback periods
on our marketing costs with steadily increasing trends:

Source: BestSecret.

(2) Customer acquisition cost.

We are generally able to maintain low marketing spend due to our viral model and in particular, our strong viral
growth dynamics, which resulted in an average NMV retention of almost 100% between 2019 and 2023, at a
limited cost and a marketing spend approximately four times lower than that of our full-price, e-commerce peers
(2.8% versus 10.9%). Furthermore, our marketing spend, although limited, creates significant returns on
investment (“ROI”) as from 2019 to 2023, for each euro we spent on marketing, we generated €5.5 of incremental
revenue (compared to our full-price, e-commerce peers, which generated €1.2 of average revenue per euro spent).
This is primarily due to approximately 76% of our customers being acquired through our viral model with our
complementary paid marketing model only ramping up in more recently penetrated markets and target segments.

**_Strong Growth Avenues to Continue our Consistent Double-Digit Growth_**

We have strong avenues to ensure sustained double-digit growth and ongoing value creation, as shown by our
results in the German market, where our online NMV has grown at a CAGR of 17.5% between 2019 and 2023,
from €364 million in 2019 to €695 million in 2023, and our increased international reach, as shown by our
international online NMV, which has grown at an CAGR of over 54% between 2019 and 2023, from €83 million
in 2019 to €468 million in 2023. Additionally, our increased focus on the luxury segment shows another path for
continued growth, with our luxury online NMV share approximately doubling between 2019 and 2023, from
around 2% in 2019 to around 4% in 2023. Operational enhancements, such as our new fulfillment center in Poland,
are set to decrease warehousing costs per item, contributing to reduced cost-to-serve and improved PCII margins.
Although our warehousing cost per item has slightly increased from €1.83 to €1.90 between 2019 and 2023, we
expect this cost to substantially decrease by 2027. Furthermore, our technology investments in AI and automation
are poised to transform core operations, enabling scalable growth with a lean team. Overall, our growth and value
creation is supported by the Elevation Strategy.

In 2021, our management shifted our strategy to accelerate our international growth and reach market leadership
across Europe. Our international growth strategy has three steps: (1) developing a relevant brand portfolio tailored
to local customer preferences, (2) localizing the customer experience by providing local language websites,
payment methods, carriers and customer care, improving shipment costs and investing in marketing, particularly
social media, to generate new customers and (3) scaling our customer base and revenues through predominately
viral growth. Our strategy has been instrumental in driving consistent double-digit expansion and delivering strong
internalization growth as illustrated by the below tables:

Furthermore, our luxury initiative, which centers on enriching our portfolio with highly desirable luxury brands
by forging direct relationships with these brands already shows promising results. We have a clear plan to continue
acquiring luxury brands, which encompasses, from a business-to-business (B2B) standpoint, the opening of two
offices in major luxury fashion capitals, Paris and Milan, the hiring of over 10 new luxury fashion and buying
experts and the launch of our Curated Platform in 2023 (which enables selected partners to sell goods directly to
BestSecret’s closed customer community) and, from a business-to-client (B2C) standpoint, the enhancing of our
customers’ user experience through the introduction of a dedicated luxury section on our platform and an overall
high-end shopping experience. These initiatives have translated into more than 20 leading luxury and designer
brands won since we launched our Elevation Strategy and over 55% of direct brand relationships being converted
within six months after the first meeting in 2023. Additionally, we recorded over 85% luxury NMV growth in the
second half of 2023 and our average luxury selling price (as compared to total average selling price) is more than
three times higher (based on the average from 2019 to 2023). This results in an increase of our luxury online NMV
share from around 2% in 2019 to around 4% in 2023.

Our business model supports our objective to grow within the luxury sector as luxury brands need support in
clearing overstock while protecting their brand equity. The luxury market is a large market segment, with the
affordable luxury and luxury market amounting to approximately €68 billion, compared to the off-price affordable
luxury and luxury market, amounting to approximately €10 billion and representing 15% off-price penetration
such luxury market. However, luxury brands need long-term support from off-price players as these brands: a)
experience continuous growth of their impaired inventory, b) the expansion of their own offline outlets is
stagnating and c) these brands are increasingly facing barriers to impaired inventory destruction (for example, the
EU ban on destruction of unsold product). In this environment, we are well-positioned to assist through our
superior value proposition, and by being one of the largest clearance partners available with significant scaling
potential.

With the aim of supporting our strong business growth, we have successfully transformed our warehousing
infrastructure over the past years. By expanding our German fulfillment center and adding a new fulfillment center
in Poland in 2023, we expanded our inventory capacity from 7.9 million items in 2019 to 16.2 million items in
2023. Our inventory capacity is expected to further grow to around 30 million items by 2027 as we gradually
increase the level of automation. We estimate that our future inventory capacity will be able to serve an additional
NMV of three billion. Furthermore, the fulfillment center in Poland in 2023 offers significant labor cost
advantages (60% cost advantage per hour versus the Germany fulfillment center) and we expect the increasing
automation in such fulfillment center to drive further cost improvements going forward.

**_We Have A Highly Resilient Financial Profile_**

We have a resilient financial profile marked by strong performance across economic cycles. Despite facing
challenges affecting the worldwide economy and overall fashion market, such as the global financial crisis and
the COVID-19 pandemic, we have nevertheless preserved a strong market position, consistently delivering
double-digit revenue and Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA growth (at a CAGR of 21.0% between 2019 and 2023).
We also have a strong cash flow generation and reinvest our cash to seek further future growth, as illustrated by
our recurring cash conversion, which averaged 50.0% in the period between 2019 and 2023 and was 61.0% in the
year ended December 31, 2023. Furthermore, our senior secured net leverage ratio (defined as the ratio of total
principal amount of senior secured net financial debt to LTM Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA) reduced from 1.6x as
of March 31, 2023 to 0.9x as of March 31, 2024. Our financial solidity, combined with a cautious leverage strategy
and our continued investment in strategic growth initiatives, position us for continued profitable growth.

**Strategy**

To build on our existing success, we have identified the following key elements of our strategy:

**_Expanding our footprint_**

Our strategic growth ambition hinges on expanding our presence, both in our core market, Germany, and
internationally. Although our business is subject to higher penetration in certain areas of Germany, we continue
to see opportunity for revenue growth within this market, which is supported by our almost 100% NMV retention,
robust customer loyalty and strong inflow of new customers. Furthermore, we recognize vast opportunities for
further international expansion. Our strategic approach to acceleration of international growth involves three steps:
(1) developing access to a relevant brand portfolio tailored to local customer preferences, (2) localizing the
customer experience by providing local language websites, payment methods, carriers and customer care,
improving shipment costs and investing in marketing, particularly social media, to generate new customers and
(3) as a final step, scaling our customer base and revenues through predominately viral growth.

**_Elevating our value proposition_**

Complementing our growth ambitions in the German and the International segments, is our luxury initiative,
which centers on enriching our portfolio with highly desirable luxury brands by forging direct relationships with
these brands. The launch of our luxury initiative in 2023 has had significant early success. As of the year ended
December 31, 2023, and since the launch of our Elevation Strategy, we have managed to win more than 20 leading
luxury and designer brands and our luxury fashion NMV experienced period-on-period growth in excess of 180%
for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Our luxury initiative is part of our overarching Elevation Strategy,

6


-----

which focuses on growing the share of highly desirable brands in our portfolio - both in the luxury and premium
segments. By winning new brands and by expanding our business with existing brands in these segments, we aim
to continue to make our assortment more appealing.

As part of our Elevation Strategy, we also enhanced our online presence by introducing a new high-end design
for our app and online shop and by adding a dedicated luxury section, thereby aligning more closely with the
appeal of luxury brands. We also established offices in the renowned fashion capitals of Paris and Milan,
underlining our commitment to expanding our ongoing international activities, and being closer to our
international brand partners. Our Elevation Strategy not only strengthens our relationships with highly desirable
premium and luxury suppliers, but also bolsters our appeal to our customers. By deepening customer relationships
through compelling offers, we continue to foster a strong community of loyal members. With our commitment to
enriching our product assortment, elevating our online platform, and refining our shopping and service
experiences, we promote the retention of existing and acquisition of new customers and pave a way forward in
the online off-price fashion market.

**The Transactions**

We intend to use the gross proceeds from the Offering (i) to repay and redeem the Existing Notes on, or soon
after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date, (ii) to fund a distribution to the shareholder of the Issuer and (iii)
to pay certain fees and expenses in relation to the Transactions. On the Issue Date, the Issuer will deposit the net
proceeds from the Offering into the Depository Account. Pursuant to the terms of the Depository Agreement, such
deposited net proceeds will be released on, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in order to
consummate the Existing Notes Redemption whereas the residual amount following the Existing Notes
Redemption shall be transferred to the Issuer. We also intend to enter into the RCF Amendment and Restatement
Agreement on or about the date of this Offering Memorandum, and we expect the RCF Amendment and
Restatement Agreement to become effective on the Issue Date.

**Our History**

BestSecret draws on a heritage of 100 years in the textile industry. In 1924, Herman Schustermann founded a
textile company in Makredwitz, Germany and relocated to Munich in the late 1940s. In the early 1950s, Benno
Borenstein established his textile business in Munich. The two companies merged in 1960, and, after the death of
Herman Schustermann, a new cooperation was established with Herman’s son, Emil Schustermann, and Benno
Borenstein as partners. While Schustermann & Borenstein initially started as a combination of two textile trading
companies with regional customer bases around Munich, ready-to-wear clothes were added to the portfolio over
the next decades and the closed membership retail business model was born.

Prior to 2007, our business operations were limited to our Schustermann & Borenstein offline retail stores in
Munich. In 2007, we launched our BestSecret online platform. In 2011, we made the BestSecret online platform
available in the Austrian market, setting the first milestone for our international expansion strategy. Since then,
we have continued our online international expansion. Today, our multi-language online platform is available
across Europe with shipping available to 27 countries. We have continued to maintain a limited physical presence
with premium and outlet stores in strategic locations, with such locations designed primarily to support our online
platform.

In 2012, the BestSecret Group’s founding families sold a majority stake of 61% of the business to Ardian. In 2014,
construction commenced on the new centralized fulfillment center in Poing, Germany (near Munich), which
became operational in early 2016 and consolidated our then-existing seven warehouses. In 2014, we expanded
our offline retail footprint through the opening of a new store in Vienna, Austria. In 2016, we acquired Swiss
Online Shopping AG, a leading off-price player in Switzerland, to further expand our online presence in Germany,
Austria and Switzerland (hereafter referred to as the DACH region). In January 2017, funds owned and managed
by Permira acquired a majority stake in the Group. In 2019 and 2020, we expanded our fulfillment center in Poing,
Germany by approximately 60% to support our business growth.

In late 2020, Dr. Moritz Hahn joined us after nine years of experience at Zalando SE where he served as a member
of the Executive Committee and held numerous senior positions. He has since built a strong leadership team of ecommerce pioneers with decades of relevant experience across the tech and e-commerce industry, complemented
by senior individuals with long-term experience at and in-depth knowledge of the Company. In early 2021, this
senior leadership team announced a new strategy which is focused on online pure-play, profitable growth across
Europe. The offline strategy was sharpened to focus on supporting our online value proposition with premium
stores designed to elevate our brand image and outlet stores to clear inventory that fails to sell online. In 2021, the

7


-----

structure and brand profile across the Group was simplified and harmonized, merging and renaming the companies
to solely feature the BestSecret name across the Group. In 2023, we launched our Elevation Strategy to grow the
share of highly desirable premium and luxury brands in our portfolio. We also enhanced our online presence by
introducing a new high-end design for our app and online shop and by adding a dedicated luxury section, thereby
aligning more closely with the appeal of luxury brands. In the same year, our new fulfillment center in Sulechów,
Poland, commenced its preliminary stage of operations. In 2024, we expanded our Sulechów fulfillment center
by 40,000 square meters to a total footprint of 120,000 square meters.

**Principal Shareholder**

Permira is a global investment firm that backs successful businesses with growth ambitions. Founded in 1985, the
firm advises funds with total committed capital of more than €80 billion and makes long-term majority and
minority investments. The Permira Funds have made more than 300 private equity investments in four key sectors:
technology, consumer, healthcare and services. Permira employs over 500 people in 15 offices across Europe,
North America, and Asia.

The Permira Funds have invested in various businesses in the DACH region, such as Engel & Völkers,
Neruaxpharm, P&I and TeamViewer. The Permira Funds also have extensive expertise in the premium and luxury
fashion space and in-depth knowledge of dealing with global brands, including Hugo Boss, Valentino, Golden
Goose and Dr. Martens.

**Risks Related to Our Business and Industry**

**_Our business depends on our ability to continuously source and present a variety and quantity of attractive_**
**_products from various popular brands at attractive prices that will satisfy our customers’ preferences and_**
**_demands._**

The success of our business depends on our ability to continuously source attractive and high-quality merchandise
from a broad selection of high-quality brands at attractive prices and in a timely manner. If we are unable to
maintain our existing relationships or build new relationships with brands on favorable commercial terms, we may
be unable to offer an appropriate selection or quantity of merchandise at discounted prices, which would reduce
the appeal of our offering. Only a few of the brand partners we work with have a continuing obligation to provide
us with merchandise at historical levels or at all. Furthermore, building new relationships with prospective brand
partners can be a lengthy and time-consuming process leading to prolonged lead times until merchandise becomes
available for our members to purchase, which in turn could lead to a decrease in customer satisfaction.

Our business depends on successful merchandise financial planning and open-to-buy management (a management
system that aligns budgets to planned inventory). If these prove inadequate, we could fail to secure and offer an
attractive inventory to our customers, which could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of
operations.

Additionally, certain goods are purchased from intermediaries rather than the brands themselves. Such goods have
an increased risk of infringing intellectual property rights of third parties. Certain brands have, in the past, alleged
that we have sold merchandise which infringes upon their intellectual property. We investigated these allegations
and determined that, in certain minor cases, the merchandise sold did infringe third party intellectual property
rights. In such cases, we may not have any viable recourse against such intermediaries, as they tend to have little
economic substance. Furthermore, any inadvertent promotion and sale of counterfeit merchandise may harm our
reputation and lead to loss of trust and customers.

Our business also depends on sufficient availability of overstock in the market, which could be adversely affected
by supply chain disruptions, changes to the distribution plans of our brand partners or an overall decline in the
fashion market. For example, the Russian invasion of Ukraine in late February 2022 has and will potentially
continue to have a wide range of supply chain implications, including increases in cost and disruption in freight
transport. Similarly, the lockdowns and the temporary port closures in China due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and
more recently, the military conflict between Israel and Hamas and its spillover effects throughout the Middle East,
including the Houthi attacks on the Red Sea, have in the past and may lead in the future to lower availability of
stock because of transportation delays and, in the case of the military conflicts, may also result in increased sea
freight rates due to the rerouting of ships around the southern tip of Africa and increased air freight rates due to
heightened demand in response to the effects of the conflict on maritime logistics. Additionally, any further
escalation of the ongoing political conflict between China and Taiwan may have a widespread effect on global
supply chains, including decreases to global economic output and decreases to global trade. See also “––Negative
_developments in global and local economic conditions in our markets could adversely impact consumer spending_
_in the fashion market.” Additionally, our brand partners may not be willing or able to fulfill our product requests_
(partially or fully) due to lack of stock, changes in their supply-chain model or aggressive competition from other
industry participants, including other off-price retailers, both online and offline, bidding against us for the same

24


-----

merchandise. Furthermore, brand partners may start managing their product relationships with sellers on a global,
rather than local level, which could adversely affect us.

As a result of our exclusive, invitation-only membership model, we must balance exclusivity and the protection
of brand equity with our growth ambitions. If we fail to strike an appropriate balance, we could fail to achieve our
desired growth or negatively affect the brand equity of our brand partners, who may decide to prevent us from
offering merchandise for sale through a particular sales channel. Our ability to build a relevant offering for our
customers through a broad assortment of desirable products in the right categories and quantities could also be
affected if we are prevented from offering merchandise through a particular sales channel.

If we are unable to secure an appropriate selection and quantity of merchandise on terms and conditions acceptable
to us, we may be unable to attract new customers and retain existing customers and consequently increase or
maintain sales, which could also diminish the attractiveness of our proposition for brand partners, limiting access
to merchandise, any one of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and
financial condition.

**_We face strong competition in our markets and such competition may intensify further._**

We are a leading European members-only destination for online off-price fashion, operating in the market for
mid-market to luxury fashion. We provide our customers with exclusive access to a sizeable portfolio of brands,
while offering our brand partners a structural solution to sell their overstock through a discreet and controlled
channel. The markets in which we operate are highly competitive. Our primary competitors are online off-price
and full-price retailers and platforms, including those devoted solely to fashion as well as other types of online
platforms and including single-brand as well as multi-brand retailers and marketplaces. In addition, we are to
some extent also competing with offline off-price and full-price retailers, such as traditional retail stores, brand
outlet stores and off-price fashion stores, due to the operation of our outlet locations and due to partially
overlapping customer demographics and supply markets. Furthermore, the rising popularity of discount and fast
fashion retailers, such as Shein and Temu, has expanded the competitive landscape, potentially paving the way
for new competitors in our market. Furthermore, we are always subject to competition imposed by new market
entrants. New competitors who enter our markets or existing offline competitors that shift to online platforms may
be successful in attracting customers, including our customers, and thereby capturing market share from us,
particularly in Germany, our core market.

Some of our current and potential future competitors may have greater financial, distribution, marketing, and other
resources than we do. Such competitors may be able to out-bid us for merchandise we would like to access, acquire
more attractive merchandise in greater quantities, deliver merchandise more rapidly, or devote more resources to
technology, order fulfillment and marketing than we can. The internet facilitates competitive entry and
comparison-shopping and renders e-commerce inherently more competitive than other retail channels. In addition,
new and enhanced technologies, including search services, may favor our competition. Also, alternative business
models may emerge that would compete with us or diminish the attractiveness or utility of our business model. In
particular, social commerce, that is, the use of social networks in the context of e-commerce transactions, as well
as the growing popularity of online secondhand fashion retail, could potentially disrupt our business model.

If we are unable to compete effectively and fail to attract our target customers to purchase our merchandise, we
could lose market share to our competitors. In addition, our brand partners allocate merchandise among ourselves
and our competitors depending on the timeliness of orders. If we are unable to act quickly when our brand partners
make their merchandise available for purchase, or if we otherwise fail to procure merchandise from our brand
partners, for example, due to lack of availability in the market or if the brand partner decides to sell it to another
competitor in the market, we could lose market share to our competitors. Furthermore, our plans to expand our
business operations into new markets and markets in which we currently have a relatively small presence may be
adversely affected by strong competition. For example, some of our competitors may already have long
established customer or brand relationships and operations in these markets, which may put them at a competitive
advantage. We cannot be certain that we will be able to compete successfully. Should competitive pressure
intensify, the resources available to adjust our operations effectively and in a timely manner could be negatively
impacted, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

**_Consolidation in the online retail fashion industry could have a material adverse effect on our business,_**
**_financial condition, and results of operations._**

The online market for off-price mid-market to luxury fashion is undergoing rapid growth and substantial change,
which has resulted in increased competition and a consolidation trend. Acquisitions or other consolidating

transactions could harm us in a number of ways, including losing customers, revenue and market share, or forcing
our company to expend greater resources to meet new or additional competitive threats, all of which could harm
our operating results. Newly formed competitors and increased competition, threatening our market position or
copying our business model, could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and
financial condition.

**_Negative developments in global and local economic conditions in our markets could adversely impact_**
**_consumer spending in the fashion market._**

We primarily sell fashion products online. Purchases of our customers are discretionary, and therefore dependent
upon the level of customer spending, particularly among affluent customers. As a result, our performance depends
on global and regional economic conditions, which have shown significant volatility in recent years. For example,
economic contraction, economic uncertainty, and the perception by our customers of weak or weakening
economic conditions, whether as a result of global pandemics, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, geopolitical
conflicts, such as the conflict in Ukraine, the military conflict between Israel and Hamas and its spillover effects
throughout the Middle East or the ongoing political conflict between China and Taiwan, or otherwise, has and
could cause a decline in the demand for the merchandise we sell. In addition, the COVID-19 pandemic, the conflict
in Ukraine or, more recently, the military conflict between Israel and Hamas and its spillover effects throughout
the Middle East or any further escalation of the ongoing political conflict between China and Taiwan, and their
respective related effects have in the past and/or may lead in the future to a disruption of our supply chain or a
decline in the supply of products produced by our brand partners, which could in turn lead to supply shortages.

The COVID-19 pandemic has in the past led and a similar global pandemic, including a resurgence of the COVID19 pandemic in the future, may lead to closure of our retail stores on a temporary or permanent basis. If we are
forced to close any of our retail stores, whether as a result of a resurgence of the COVID-19 pandemic or a different
global pandemic, or for any other reason, there is no guarantee that we would be able to reduce or fully eliminate
the fixed costs related to the operation and maintenance of such stores. For example, there is no guarantee that we
would be able to terminate the relevant leases, secure subleases or implement any other cost-defraying
arrangement for the remainder of the lease terms.

Furthermore, among other circumstances, factors such as inflation, higher unemployment levels, rising interest
rates, reduced access to credit, recessionary economic cycles, increases in taxes or perceived or actual declines in
disposable consumer income and wealth may influence changes in discretionary consumer spending.

Our online platform is available in multiple languages and offers shipping to 27 European countries, with the
majority of our revenue currently generated in Germany, although an increasing portion of our revenue is
generated in the international markets. A negative development, contraction or lack of growth in the economies
of Germany or the other European countries where we operate or may operate in the future, and in overall
macroeconomic conditions, could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial
condition. We may be more affected by such economic weakness or uncertainty than some of our competitors
with more diversified international operations.

Macroeconomic weakness and uncertainty, including inflation, slower growth or recession, new or increased
tariffs and other barriers to trade, changes to fiscal and monetary policy, tighter credit, higher interest rates, high
unemployment and currency fluctuations make it more difficult for us to manage our operations and accurately
forecast financial results. Worldwide economies have recently experienced inflationary pressures, with price
increases seen across many sectors globally. In response to inflationary pressures, central banks have made steep
increases in interest rates, which result in increases in the interest rates available to us on any potential new debt
financing for our operations. Whether the present inflationary pressures will transition to a long-term inflationary
environment and the effects of such a development in the sector in which we operate are uncertain. Additionally,
the monetary tightening implemented by a series of central banks around the world in order to curb inflationary
pressures has also significantly increased the probability of an economic recession in the short-to-medium term.
For example, Germany, our home market, which experienced a long period of stable economic growth since the
financial crisis of 2007-2008, entered into an economic recession in 2023, when its real GDP declined by 0.3%
(0.1% after adjustment for calendar effects) according to the German Federal Statistical Office, Destatis
(Statistisches Bundesamt). Although Germany’s gross domestic product reported a 0.7% increase in 2023
compared to 2019, the year before the COVID-19 pandemic began, the deep labor shortages in skilled high-growth
sectors, the weak global economic growth paired with high interest rates and the military conflict between Israel
and Hamas and its spillover effects throughout the Middle East, including the Houthi attacks on the Red Sea and
their effect on global logistics will likely continue to dampen economic prospects in Germany, and more generally,
Europe, in the short term. While Germany still generates most of our revenue (60.1% in the year ended

Geopolitical tensions, including but not limited to tensions between Russia and its neighboring countries,

**_Our industry and the sale of our products are subject to seasonal fluctuations and unfavorable weather._**

The industry in which we operate is seasonal in nature, and our revenue, profits, liquidity and inventory levels are
therefore subject to seasonal fluctuations. For example, we typically experience an increase in sales in the fourth
quarter of the year due to special sales events (e.g., Cyber Week) and the Christmas shopping season. In the year
ended December 31, 2023, revenue in the fourth quarter accounted for 33.0% of our total revenue for the year.
These seasonal influences have a direct impact on our results of operations and overall profitability. Any factors
that deter customers from purchasing online or visiting our stores during these periods could have a
disproportionate effect on our results of operations for the entire fiscal year.

In addition, atypical weather conditions may impact our sales and operating results. When the weather is warmer
than expected in the autumn and winter months, our customers tend to purchase fewer winter collection items.
Similarly, when the weather is cooler than expected in the summer months, our customers tend to purchase fewer
summer collection items. During times of such unfavorable or unpredicted weather conditions, we may be required
to lower our prices, negatively impacting our margins and our profit. If we cannot offset the lower-sales seasons
with those having stronger sales, our business, financial condition and results of operations may be adversely
affected.

Seasonal fluctuations also impact our working capital, liquidity levels and inventory. We incur additional expenses
in the preparation for the increased demand we typically expect leading up to, and around, the special sales events
(e.g., Cyber Week sale) and Christmas season and other peak selling periods and therefore must carry a significant
amount of inventory before such periods, which impacts our liquidity.

If too many customers access our website within a short period of time due to increased demand or unexpectedly
strong peaks arising, for example, in the context of special sales events such as those aforementioned, our
businesses may experience system interruptions that make our website unavailable or prevent us from efficiently
fulfilling orders, which may reduce the volume of goods we are able to offer or sell and the attractiveness of our
products and services. In addition, we may be unable to adequately staff our fulfillment networks and customer
service centers during these peak periods and delivery and other third-party shipping (or carrier) companies may
be unable to meet the seasonal demand. Seasonal products, such as winter clothing, which delivery is delayed
may, as a result of such delays, only be sold in the next season and may increase storage costs.

Our quarterly results of operations may also fluctuate significantly as a result of a variety of other factors,
including but not limited to unfavorable weather, age and quantity of inventory at period end and the timing,
extent and impact of government-imposed restrictions, including closed borders or other restrictions on business
activities resulting from new legislation related to any public health emergency, pandemic or otherwise. As a
result, historical period-to-period comparisons of our results of operations are not necessarily indicative of future

27


-----

period-to-period results. The results of a single fiscal quarter may not be an indication of our annual results or our
future performance.

Increasing weather anomalies could complicate forecasting seasonal demand. Natural disasters, such as storms,
tornadoes, floods, earthquakes or other major weather disasters may also have a negative impact on our business.
Our inability to compensate for seasonal fluctuations and adapt to weather conditions may have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_If sensitive information about our customers is disclosed, our customers may curtail use of our sites, we may_**
**_be exposed to liability and our reputation would suffer, and disclosure of our confidential information could_**

We operate apps, websites and other data systems through which we collect, maintain, transmit and store
information about our customers, brand partners and others, including personal information, as well as other
confidential and proprietary information. In addition, we gather and retain information about our employees in
the normal course of business. We also employ third-party service providers that store, process and transmit
proprietary, personal, and confidential information on our behalf. Furthermore, we rely on a variety of security
measures, including encryption and authentication technology licensed from third parties in an effort to securely
transmit confidential and sensitive information, including but not limited to credit card details.

Any compromise or breach of our security measures, or those of our third-party service providers, could violate
applicable privacy and data security laws, including the General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) as well
as other applicable laws, and cause significant legal and financial risks, adverse publicity, or a loss of confidence
in our security measures. See “—We are subject to numerous laws and regulations with respect to data protection
_and failure to comply with such laws and regulations may result in litigation and administrative or arbitration_
_proceedings and/or significantly damage our relationship with our customers”._

Customer data may be misappropriated as a result of computer viruses, telecommunications failures, electronic
break-ins and similar disruptions. If we or our third-party service providers experience, or are believed to have
experienced, security breaches that result in problems to our sites’ performance or availability or the loss or
corruption of, or unauthorized access to or disclosure of, personal data or confidential information, our customers
may become unwilling to provide us the information necessary to make purchases on our sites. Existing customers
may also decrease their purchases or close their accounts altogether. We could also face potential liability and
litigation as a result of security breaches, our online content or other consumer privacy concerns, which may not
be adequately covered by insurance. Any of these results could harm our growth prospects, our business, and our
reputation.

Furthermore, certain employees have access to sensitive confidential information relating to our business,
especially relating to the functioning of our apps and websites, our proprietary machine learning algorithms, and
big data infrastructure. While we have confidentiality agreements and technical measures in place, we cannot
assure that third parties or the general public never gain access to such information. Any ineffective protection of
such information relating to our business might materially weaken our market position and thus adversely affect
our business and operations.

**_We are exposed to the risk of security breaches, including cyber-attacks, and unauthorized use of one or more_**
**_of our websites, databases, online security systems or computerized logistics management systems._**

Like other online platforms, we are vulnerable to the risk of security breaches, including real or perceived
cyberattacks and unauthorized use of one or more of our websites, databases, online security systems or
computerized logistics management systems. While we take extensive steps to protect the security, integrity and
confidentiality of sensitive and confidential information (e.g., security policies, firewall, and internal Security
Operation Centre), our security practices or those of our third-party service providers may be insufficient and third
parties may breach our systems (e.g., through Trojans, spyware, ransomware or other malware attacks, or breaches
by our employees or third-party service providers). Such attacks or breaches which may result in shutdowns of
our sites, loss or corruption of data or unauthorized use or disclosure of information. Such attacks might lead to
blackmailing attempts, forcing us to pay substantial amounts to release our captured data or resulting in the
unauthorized release of such data, or to identity theft or unauthorized purchases, requiring us to pay compensation
to the victims. Cyberattacks could also target our logistics, supply or office systems, which could result in order
fulfillment delays, leading to cancelled orders and a subsequent decline in revenue, as well as reputational
damages. We have been subject to attempted cyber, phishing or social engineering attacks in the past and may
continue to be subject to such attacks in the future. As we gain greater visibility, we may face a higher risk of

-----

being targeted by cyberattacks. We may also need to devote significant resources to protect against security
breaches or to address problems caused by breaches, which may require us to divert resources from the growth
and expansion of our business.

We and our third-party service providers may not have the resources or technical sophistication to anticipate or
prevent all such cyberattacks. Moreover, techniques used to obtain unauthorized access to systems change
frequently and may not be known until launched against us or our third-party service providers, and consequently
it may be impossible to properly secure our systems. In addition, technical advances or a continued expansion and
increased complexity of our IT infrastructure, as well as non-technical issues, including intentional or inadvertent
actions by our employees, our third-party service providers, or their personnel, could increase the likelihood of
security breaches. As we have significantly increased the number of employees working remotely following the
COVID-19 pandemic, and as our businesses’ vendors and other business partners continue to work remotely as
well, our business and our partners may be more vulnerable to cyber-attacks. Increasingly, unauthorized parties
are exploiting access they gain to third party vendors to target companies that do business with these vendors, and
this may include third party vendors with whom we do business.

Advances in computer capabilities, new technological discoveries or other developments have increased and could
further increase the frequency or likelihood of security breaches. In addition, security breaches can also occur as
a result of non-technical issues, including intentional or inadvertent breaches by our employees or by persons with
whom we have commercial relationships, including third-party developers, consultants, outsourced customer
support or operational personnel of hosting providers (e.g., Microsoft, Noris AG) with direct access to databases
and customer-related services.

The materialization of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and prospects as well as our reputation.

**_Any failure to operate, maintain, integrate and scale our information technology systems could result in_**
**_customer dissatisfaction, loss of revenue or subject us to claims for damages._**

Our business, as an online platform with physical retail presence, is dependent on the smooth functioning of our
information technology systems, especially our internet and mobile infrastructure, as well as third-party
infrastructure such as Microsoft Azure, which are critical to our business and inherently subject to various
operating risks. For example, our offering is founded on our vertically integrated, proprietary technology platform

to analyze a broad range of customer data, tracking individual journeys and ensuring efficient spending of our
marketing resources. Our reputation and ability to acquire, retain and serve our customers are dependent upon the
reliable performance of our apps and websites and their underlying network infrastructure. As our customer base
and the amount of information shared on our apps and websites continue to grow, we will require additional
network capacity and computing power. In addition, we need to maintain reliable internet and mobile networks
with the necessary speed, data capacity and security, as well as ensuring timely development of complementary
products. Furthermore, we currently rely and expect to continue to rely on third parties in part to maintain and
develop our computer hardware and software.

The operation of our technology systems is expensive and complex, and due to that complexity, could result in
operational failures. Certain of our technology platforms have long development cycles and comparatively low
productivity, resulting in extended periods required to introduce new features as well as high development costs.
In addition, we are exposed to the risk of our technology systems being undersized and functionally maladjusted
or incompatible with certain electronic devices that are used by our customers. Our customers may also find our
websites difficult to use or may be unwilling to use our online platform for other reasons. In addition, our
customers may lack confidence in the security of our online platform and may consequently be unwilling to share
personal information with us through the online platform. In the event that our customer base or the amount of
traffic on our websites grows more quickly than anticipated, we may be required to incur significant additional
costs to enhance the underlying network infrastructure. Inadequate performance of our technology systems,
whether due to telecommunication problems, software errors, inadequate capacity at IT centers, fire, power
outages or damage, attacks by third parties, computer viruses and the delayed or failed implementation of new
computer systems or other unexpected events or causes, could affect the security or availability of our apps and
websites, prevent customers from accessing our apps and websites and result in limited capacity, reduced demand,
processing delays and loss of customers. Our existing safety systems, data backup, access protection, user
management and IT emergency planning may not be sufficient to prevent information loss or disruptions to our
IT infrastructure. Any actual or perceived failure to maintain the performance, reliability, security and availability

of our products and technology systems to the satisfaction of our customers and certain regulators could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

tested during actual disasters or similar events and may not effectively permit us to continue to run our business
in the event of any problems with respect to the data that we use. Therefore, we cannot provide any assurances
that these types of events will not occur in the future. If our cloud service partners fail, we may experience
downtime on our apps and websites which could reduce the attractiveness of our apps and websites to customers.

result in regulatory inquiries or other proceedings.

**_If we fail to adopt new technologies or adapt our websites, mobile apps and systems to changing customer_**

To remain competitive, we must continue to enhance and improve the responsiveness, functionality and features
of our online platforms, including our websites and mobile apps. The internet and the e-commerce industry are

learning technologies, frequent introductions of new products and services embodying new technologies and the

**_Inability to forecast our business accurately could prevent us from properly planning expenses and process_**
**_capacity._**

We base our current and future expense levels on our forecasts of our business and estimates of future revenue.
Such future revenue and results of operations are difficult to forecast because they generally depend on the volume,
timing and type of orders we receive, all of which are uncertain. Seasonal variations in our inventories, working
capital requirements and cash flows, among other things, also increase the difficulty of our financial forecasting
and could adversely affect our ability to accurately predict financial results. For any given season, a substantial
portion of our expenses is incurred in advance, and therefore fixed, due to the seasonality of demand for our
products and the necessity of purchasing merchandise with significant lead times. As a result, we may be unable
to adjust our spending in a timely manner to compensate for any unexpected shortfall in revenue, which could
have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.

**_If we are unable to manage our inventory, or our online presence and store network in line with customer_**
**_demand, or if we are unable to otherwise forecast our business accurately, our sales levels and profitability_**
**_may decline._**

The off-price market for mid-market to luxury fashion is driven in part by fashion and beauty trends, and
consequently, the merchandise we sell is subject to changing consumer demands and preferences. Consumer
preferences regarding fashion design, quality, sustainability, and price tend to change rapidly. Hence, accurately
forecasting the selection and required quantities of such products in future periods is difficult. Accelerated by
short-term trends and the influence of social media on consumer demand, the popularity of products can change
significantly between the time products are ordered and the date of sale. In addition, the lead times we must incur
in receiving merchandise from our brand partners could pose challenges by increasing, in some cases significantly,
the time it takes us to respond to changes in product trends, consumer demand and market prices. Our success
depends in large part on our ability to anticipate, gauge, react and adapt to changing consumer demands in a timely
manner through the leveraging of our buying teams’ decision-making, experience, and relationships with brand
partners. Insufficient controls within the purchasing process may lead to unapproved or incorrect orders and may
result in financial disadvantages for the Group due to non-sellable inventory or liquidity risks.

To be responsive to shifting customer tastes, we must manage our inventory levels closely, including through
identifying market trends and seasonality. If we misjudge, fail to identify, or fail to react swiftly to changes in
consumer preferences and market trends, our sales could decrease, and we could see a significant increase in our
inventory levels. If we are left with high levels of unsold or returned stock, or if our inventory provisions are
inadequate, our storage capacity could be negatively impacted and we could be required to mark down some of
our merchandise, which could lower our operating profits and have a significant negative impact on our business,
financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Conversely, if we underestimate consumer interest in our
merchandise, we may experience inventory shortages, unfulfilled orders, increased distribution expenses and
lower revenue and profitability than we could otherwise have achieved. Inventory shortages could lead to
customer dissatisfaction and adversely impact our reputation and brand image.

As a result of the aforementioned factors, our future business strategies, practices, and results may not meet
expectations or respond quickly enough to customer demand, and we may face operational difficulties in adjusting

to any changes, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial

**_We depend on a reliable and efficient supply chain, which includes our fulfillment and returns centers,_**
**_transport service providers, third-party carriers that deliver merchandise to our online customers, and stores._**
**_Capacity constraints, interruptions or other failures in our supply chain could materially and adversely affect_**
**_our business, results of operations and financial condition._**

The profitability of our business depends on our ability to successfully process and deliver our customers’ orders.
Our ability to process and fill orders accurately and timely depends on the efficient, uninterrupted operation of
our fulfillment centers, in particular, our most significant ones in Poing, Germany and Sulechów, Poland, as well
as our warehouse management IT system. Our main fulfillment center is, therefore, critical to our business. If
operations at our fulfillment or returns centers were interrupted due to factors including, but not limited to, natural
disasters (such as flooding or fire), labor disruptions (such as labor strikes, shortages of temporary workers or
ethical disputes), technical defects, accidents, inappropriate storage of hazardous goods or any other reason, it
would have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position. In addition, due
to the high level of integration between our fulfillment centers and points of sale, any interruption of logistics at
our fulfillment centers would also have a significant adverse effect on our ability to supply our customers and
could result in customer dissatisfaction and harm to our reputation. A number of factors, many of which are
beyond our control, could disrupt the operation of our supply chain and jeopardize our ability to receive, process
and deliver our customers’ orders. System interruptions in any of our own or externally operated technology
platforms and services could delay or prevent our receipt of customer orders, shipments or returns.

We are constantly monitoring our fulfillment and logistics capacity to keep up with those requirements and match
our continued growth. However, we cannot rule out that our significant and continued growth results in our
warehouse capacities being brought to their limits faster than anticipated. Due to the increasing levels of utilization
of our existing fulfillment and returns centers, our new fulfillment center in Sulechów, Poland, commenced
operations in 2023, providing us with additional flexibility, addressing our current needs, and positioning us to
handle additional future growth. This fulfillment center was expanded in 2024 by 40,000 square meters to a total
footprint of 120,000 square meters. However, we are still in the process of increasing its actual storage capacity
and throughput technology by installing the first picktower on one of our facilities and automation equipment.
Any incorrect assumptions regarding the necessary size, the technical design and the level of automation required
of this new facility or unexpected cost overruns, poor planning, delays in reaching full operations or other
unforeseen factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial
condition. In addition, as the new fulfillment center’s operations ramp up and until it reaches full operation, our
increasingly complex order fulfillment operation could have an adverse effect on our ability to supply our
customers, including as a result of split orders and orders that require movement between warehouses. As of
March 31, 2024, our total capital expenditure for this project amounted to €37.0 million. We currently anticipate
that the new fulfillment center in Poland will require additional capital expenditure across the years ending
December 31, 2024, through December 31, 2027. There can be no guarantee, however, that volatile raw material
prices and inflation will not cause our projected capital expenditure to be inaccurate or that we will be able to raise
additional financing on favorable terms or at all. Also, as we continue to grow and expand internationally, it is not
certain that we will be able to find suitable fulfillment center sites on commercially acceptable terms to support
any future expansion plans. We might also need to increase our capital expenditures more than anticipated in order
to increase the capacity of our logistics infrastructure. Any failure in the expansion of our fulfillment and logistics
infrastructure as our business expands could materially impact our growth strategy.

Our ability to deliver orders to our customers within a time frame that meets customer expectations also depends
on efficient internal processes as well as on third-party service providers to whom we have outsourced certain
processes such as the handling of bulky goods or returns, and third-party delivery companies in each of the
countries in which we operate. Any disruptions to these processes could also have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations and financial condition. We also rely on these third-party service providers for the
handling of certain processes and a limited number of third-party carriers, including DHL and Hermes, for the
delivery of merchandise to our fulfillment and return centers as well as for delivery to online customers. We are
therefore exposed to any failures or shortcomings by these service providers or carriers, including delivery delays
or damage, loss, or theft of goods.

Furthermore, if we are not able to negotiate acceptable pricing and other terms with these entities, if they
significantly increase their charges or they experience performance problems, including as a result of inflationary
pressures and the current macroeconomic environment, it could negatively impact our customer experience. Any
breakdown or disruption of the activities of these service providers or carriers resulting from, among other things,

If the manufacturing, delivery or supply chain management processes relating to our merchandise are disrupted

Our online platform is available in multiple languages and offers shipping to 27 European countries, with the

**_Our investments to grow our customer base through paid customer acquisition and viral growth and to retain_**
**_a loyal customer base may not be effective._**

Maintaining and growing our loyal customer base is critical to our success and profitability. In an environment
characterized by increasing levels of promotions and customer discounts, the growth of our customer base and
sales depends on the success of our general marketing activities, our incentive programs for customer referrals
from existing customers and our paid customer acquisition activities. We rely on social media to support the
positioning of our offering, extending invites to acquire new customers, increase the number of customer visits to
our websites, the number of orders and the basket size per order. In particular, we depend heavily on Meta
platforms (e.g., Facebook and Instagram), as our most-used paid customer acquisition marketing channel. Changes
to the terms and conditions of the relevant providers could limit our ability to communicate through social media.
These services may also change their algorithms or interfaces, including without notification, which may reduce
our visibility or increase our costs.

Our growth and profitability are dependent on our viral customer growth model, with existing customers inviting
their friends and families to join our community. In order to build on this structural customer growth, we have
recently increased our investments related to customer acquisition in underpenetrated regions and countries, and
we expect to continue to invest in attracting new customers. Paid social marketing (performance marketing and
social media marketing), which is geared to a critical, selected target group and closely aligned with our brand
partners, is our principal instrument to enter new opportunities in existing markets and new markets. Our
investments in viral marketing, paid customer acquisition and customer loyalty may prove ineffective. We also
use e-mail newsletters, app push notifications and other messaging services in order to promote our platform,
inform customers of our product offering and/or the status of their transactions. Changes in how webmail services
organize and prioritize e-mails could reduce the number of customers opening our e-mails. For example, several
service providers organize incoming e-mails into categories. Such tools and features could result in our e-mails
and other messages being shown as “spam”, “junk” or otherwise as lower-priority messages to our customers,
which could reduce the likelihood of customers opening or responding positively to them. Certain customers may
experience dissatisfaction and cease to use our platform if they perceive themselves to be oversaturated with
advertising campaigns or newsletters or otherwise exposed to social media, e-mail or text message “flooding.”
Our customers may also lack interest in the content of our e-mail messages, or such messages may fail to be
delivered or may be delayed in their delivery for technical reasons.
