**_Operational disruptions at our fulfillment centers could have a material adverse effect on our business, results_**
**_of operations and financial condition._**

We currently operate two fulfillment centers in Poing, Germany and Suchelów, Poland. We have two additional
warehouses in Brieselang and Großbeeren that will close in the third quarter of 2024 and will be replaced by a
new warehouse in Slubice, Poland. Our fulfillment centers are critical to our business. If operations at our
fulfillment centers were interrupted due to factors including, but not limited to, natural disasters (such as flooding
or fire), man-made disruptions (such as labor strikes), technical defects, accidents, epidemics or any other reason,
it would have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position. In addition,
although since 2019 we outsourced our returns’ handling to a third-party provider in Poland, due to the high level
of integration between our fulfillment centers and points of sale, any interruption of logistics at our fulfillment
center would also have a significant adverse effect on our ability to supply our customers and could result in
customer dissatisfaction and harm to our reputation. Any disruptions at our sites, either due to problems with our
supply of merchandise or any of the other reasons aforementioned, could also have a material adverse effect on
our business, results of operations and financial condition.

**_If we are unable to price our products competitively, our business, financial condition and results of operations_**
**_could be negatively impacted._**

As our business model is focused on selling branded fashion products at reduced prices, the price at which we
offer our products is the most important factor for being competitive in our market. Price is of great importance
to most customers, and price transparency and comparability continues to increase, particularly as a result of
digital technology. The ability of consumers to compare prices on a real-time basis puts additional pressure on us
to maintain competitive prices. Our current and potential future competitors may be able to secure more favorable
pricing terms from brand partners, adopt more aggressive pricing policies, or otherwise offer similar merchandise
at more attractive prices. If we offer products at higher prices than our competitors, our customers may choose to
shop with our competitors, which could result in a loss of customers and revenue. We are therefore dependent on
the performance of our sourcing and pricing processes, including on our pricing solution, to provide the right
pricing recommendations. We currently price our inventory through a combination of manual initial pricing,
followed by automatic adjustment through the use of an algorithm. Poor pricing decisions could lead to offering
items at prices that are too low or pricing items uncompetitively high. Furthermore, retailers and brands set their
own retail prices for consumers, which can include promotional and sales period discounts. Such discounts by
these parties may adversely affect the relative value of overstock offered for sale with us. In order to attract buyers
to our online platform, the prices for the overstock merchandise we sell may need to be lowered in order to
compete with discounted pricing employed by retailers and brands for the items sold directly by them (which we
refer to as “discount aggressiveness”).

Our prices also depend in part on our sourcing and logistics costs which in turn depend on the development of
prices for certain raw materials, in particular certain textile raw materials, as well as fuel. We are typically also
impacted by carrier-charge increases, as our brand partners and third-party service providers attempt to pass along
these increases to us. Although we may attempt to pass on cost increases to our customers by increasing selling
prices through regular price reviews and adjustments, this might impact our profitability. Moreover, any price

35


-----

increases could adversely affect our sales and, to the extent a decision to increase discount rates in order to remain
competitive in the market is required, it could further reduce our profitability. During periods of declining input
or fuel prices, customer demand may also require that we sell our products at lower prices or may restrict our
ability to increase prices, in spite of the fact that we may use goods that were purchased at higher prices or that
we are forced to incur higher shipping costs, thereby negatively impacting our margins. The volatility in our
sourcing and logistics costs and our limited ability to pass them on to customers may adversely affect our business
and financial condition.

**_We source the majority of our merchandise on the basis of purchase orders with our brand partners, and the_**
**_lack of formal supply agreements could impact our ability to maintain these relationships._**

Consistent with customary practice in our industry, we only enter into long-term agreements with brand partners
in exceptional cases and, therefore, our relationships with many of our brand partners are not based on formalized
supply agreements but, rather, the regular submission of purchase orders or price agreements renegotiated
periodically between the parties on order forms. The lack of these formal, long-term agreements may result in a
less precise definition of the parties’ respective rights and may, in the event of a disagreement between the parties
as it pertains to the terms of the purchase and supply of merchandise, result in disputes or conflicts which may
adversely impact our ability to continue sourcing a particular brand or from a particular brand partner, although
we have recently introduced general terms and conditions, terms of delivery and chemical restrictions as part of
our ongoing relationships with certain brand partners following a brand clustering approach in order to reduce the
risks typically associated to this contracting model.

**_We are subject to certain risks in connection with the quality and timely delivery of our pre-order private label_**
**_merchandise and our relationships with the manufacturers of such merchandise._**

A small share of our sales relates to our private label merchandise, which we source, for example, from suppliers
in Turkey, Spain, Portugal, India, and China. These suppliers may also manufacture merchandise for our
competitors. Our agreements with the manufacturers of our private label merchandise, which set forth the
production and delivery of private label merchandise, are typically based on an order-by-order concept for each
private label brand, rather than long-term supply agreements. In case an agreement with a private label supplier is
terminated, there can be no assurance that we will find other suppliers that will be able to produce comparable
replacement merchandise for us at competitive prices or at all.

Since we only have limited control over manufacturers of our private label merchandise, there is no guarantee that
this merchandise will continue to meet our specifications. Furthermore, any breach or perceived breach of relevant
laws, regulations, permits, or licenses relating to the private label merchandise sold by us, or failure to achieve or
maintain particular ethical business practices and standards, including with respect to environmental, social, and
corporate governance (“ESG”) matters, could also lead to adverse publicity, which could in turn materially
adversely affect the reputation of our private label brands, or even the Group, damage our customer relationships
and lead to a decline in our sales.

As we are the “responsible person” for our private label merchandise within the context of the regulations on
product safety applicable to our merchandise in the jurisdictions in which we operate, any quality defect could
lead to customer claims, administrative or criminal proceedings and, potentially, penalties. We could also face
damage to our own private label brands’ reputation.

**_Our operations may be interrupted or otherwise adversely affected as a result of failures in our IT systems._**

Our success depends on the continuous and uninterrupted availability of our IT systems, particularly to process
customer transactions and to manage inventory levels, purchases and deliveries of our merchandise. Over the past
few years, we have developed a sophisticated IT system which supports our apps and websites, customer service,
supplier connectivity, communications and the monitoring of customer sales and improved management of
inventories. As our operations grow in size, scope and complexity, we need to continuously improve and upgrade
our systems and infrastructure to offer an increasing number of user-enhanced services, features and
functionalities, while maintaining or improving the reliability and integrity of our systems and infrastructure.

A range of factors beyond our control, such as telecommunication problems, software errors, inadequate capacity
at IT centers, fire, power outages or damage, attacks by third parties, computer viruses and the delayed or failed
implementation of new computer systems, could interfere with the availability of our IT systems. Any material
disruption or slowdown of our systems could cause information, including data related to purchases of
merchandise, to be lost or delayed, which could result in delays in the delivery of products to customers or lost

-----

sales or impair our ability to manage our inventories. Our existing safety systems, data backup, access protection,
user management and IT emergency planning may not be sufficient to prevent information loss or disruptions to
our IT systems. In addition, if changes in technology cause our IT systems to become obsolete, or if our IT systems
are inadequate to handle our growth, our reputation among our customers may be damaged. Any failure to properly
guard against the interruption or malfunctioning of our IT systems could have a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Failure to secure or preserve the value of our brand partners’ brand equity could negatively impact our_**
**_financial results._**

We depend on our relationships with, and the supply of merchandise from, our brand partners. To maintain these
relationships and ensure a supply of merchandise from our brand partners, we must secure and preserve the
commercial value that derives from consumer perception of the merchandise produced by such brand partners
(i.e., their brand equity). Brand equity is based on a variety of factors, including level of public awareness of a
brand, quality perceptions regarding the brand and the perception of exclusivity surrounding the brand. The brand
equity of our brand partners could diminish significantly due to a number of factors, such as lowered customer
perceptions of brand value or exclusivity due to their brands being offered through off-price online platforms,
including our BestSecret online platform.

Negative publicity, including, but not limited to, negative online reviews on social media from dissatisfied
customers or media reports related to our offering whether or not accurate, can deter other potential customers
from using our e-commerce platform and lead to a negative impact on the value of the brand equity of our brand
partners through their association with our platform.

If our brand partners perceive a negative impact on their brand equity as a result of their partnership with us, they
may choose to lower the amount of merchandise they make available to us for purchase or terminate their
partnership with us entirely, which could have an adverse material effect on the attractiveness of our offering to
our customers and consequently on our financial condition and results of operations.

**_Our strategy to continue to expand our business in Germany and internationally may fail or advance at a_**
**_slower pace than planned._**

The success of our online growth in existing markets and expansion into new markets may be affected if we fail
to adapt our offering to local consumer requirements, if we fail to source sufficient merchandise to attract new
customers and retain existing customers or if we fail to adequately scale the supporting operational infrastructure.

The success of our expansion may also be affected if we fail to correctly estimate customer demand in local
markets. This risk may be higher in new markets in which we operate, where our less established position makes
it more difficult to assess customer demand and the appeal of our product offering. Our capital and other
expenditures may also be higher than expected due to cost overruns, unexpected delays, or other unforeseen
factors. In addition, if we fail to execute our expansion strategy in a discreet manner, our brand partner
relationships may deteriorate, and we may lose certain brand partners. If our expansion strategy is not successful
or advances at a slower pace than planned, our competitive position and our profitability and growth may be
negatively affected. In addition, any failure by us to anticipate or respond to market demand, control our operating
costs, or otherwise effectively address any challenges that arise as we attempt to implement our strategy, could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

to us. Any delay in improving these processes or reaching an appropriate level of staffing may result in business

**_Our compliance management system and internal controls may not be sufficient to adequately protect us from_**
**_all legal or financial risks, especially with regards to our business in certain countries where corruption and_**
**_money laundering may be considered widespread._**

To protect us against legal risks and other potential harm, we established a group-wide, centralized compliance
management system that comprises several specific compliance programs (e.g., anti-corruption, anti-money
laundering, fraud prevention and conflict of interest, economic sanctions compliance and antitrust as well as
human rights), including a group-wide Code of Conduct which outlines the general rules of behavior for our
management and employees, as well as our business ethics. Our central compliance function is carried out by our
compliance department, legal department and our managing directors and is complemented by external law firms.
Direct reporting lines to the management board and our parent company’s supervisory board are set up. Yet, these
codes, guidelines and policies and the oversight of our internal compliance and legal departments might not be
sufficient to prevent all unauthorized practices, legal infringements, corruption, and fraud—especially regarding
purchasing practices—or other adverse consequences of non-compliance within our organization or by or on
behalf of our employees or third parties. Any compliance failure could harm our reputation and have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

To comply with legal requirements as well as to achieve our corporate goals efficiently and effectively, as an
integrated part of the Corporate Governance structure, we have established a formally documented, tool-based
group-wide risk management system. Having a well-defined and uniform risk management system in place allows
us to recognize, assess, manage and monitor risks that might potentially threaten our operations now and in the
future. Through early detection of risk-related issues and implementation of suitable countermeasures we
minimize our risk exposure. Our central risk management is carried out by the risk manager, who represents the
link between the risk owners, managing directors and our parent company’s supervisory board, and continuously
develops and improves our risk management system to ensure its completeness and correctness. However, as we
operate in a very dynamic environment, our risk management system and periodical risk assessment might not be
sufficient to ensure that all potential events impacting our organization are timely identified and promptly
mitigated, also due to risks characteristic that their probability of occurrence and potential impact on organization
cannot be determined with certainty.

To identify, monitor and control internal risks related to our business processes we established a group-wide

Despite our internal control systems, our employees, agents or authorized persons may have been engaged or may

Any violation or breach of these laws and regulations could affect our overall reputation and, depending on the

**_We are subject to numerous laws and regulations with respect to data protection and failure to comply with_**
**_such laws and regulations may result in litigation and administrative or arbitration proceedings and/or_**
**_significantly damage our relationship with our customers._**

We process sensitive customer data as part of our members-only business model. A fundamental requirement for
online commerce and communications is the secure handling and transmission of confidential information over
public networks. However, we cannot exclude that any advances in computer capabilities, new discoveries in the
field of cryptography or other developments will not compromise or breach the systems we use to protect
transactional and personal data.

Additionally, we are subject to a host of laws and regulations governing the collection, use, retention, sharing and
security of this personal data, including the GDPR, which is effective since May 25, 2018, as well as other
applicable laws. Under the GDPR, we, as a data controller, must implement certain specific technical and
organizational measures to protect the personal data we collect depending on the amount of and potential risk for
the personal data processed. In order to comply with the GDPR, we have implemented a data protection
organization and, among other actions, we have appointed an external data protection officer. These data
protection organizations, together with the external data protection officer, monitor all of our measures associated
with data protection, including group-wide training for existing and new employees.

Any compromise or breach of our security measures, or those of our third-party service providers, could violate
applicable privacy and data security laws, including the GDPR, as well as other applicable laws, and cause
significant legal and financial risks, adverse publicity, or a loss of confidence in our security measures.
Furthermore, a breach of the GDPR or a failure to comply with other applicable data protection laws or regulations
could lead to us becoming subject to governmental investigations, fines, and private claims for compensation from
individuals whose personal data was involved. In the event of such a personal data breach, we could be required
to notify applicable government authorities (within a certain time period) and/or potential victims if the breach in
question may pose a high risk to the rights of these victims. This could have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations and financial position (for example, the GDPR provides severe fines in case of
infringements of up to €20 million or 4% of global turnover on a group basis, whichever is greater and depending
on the respective breach for non-compliance with GDPR provisions). The need to comply with data protection
legislation conveys significant controlling, operational and reputational risks which could affect us in a number
of ways including, for example, by making it more difficult to maintain and expand our marketing database and
also by giving rise to potential litigation relating to alleged misuse of personal data. While we have taken out

-----

cyber-security insurance, we cannot be certain that our insurance coverage concerning this and other risks will
cover any liabilities that we might actually incur fully, partially or at all, or that such insurance will continue to
be available to us on economically reasonable terms, or at all.

New and more stringent data protection laws, regulations or developments and changes in consumer behavior
could interfere with our strategies to use privacy-related information for our marketing efforts and could also have
an adverse effect on our business and results of operations.

Current case law may also require us to change our current data protection strategies. For example, the “Schrems
II” ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union of July 16, 2020, provides that special care and safeguards
must be taken when transferring personal data to countries outside the EU/EEA. This decision has greatly
increased the legal requirements imposed on data exporters for transfers of personal data from EU-countries to
non-EU countries, which are deemed to have an inadequate data protection level compared to the standards
imposed in the EEA (including, amongst others, the United States). Ensuring compliance with changing and/or
stricter standards requires resources to continuously review and, as necessary, replace, amend, or supplement the
international data transfer mechanisms which we currently rely on, including corporate binding rules, standard
contractual clauses, and adequate data processing agreements with our business partners. The resulting
mechanisms and procedures may increase the expenses associated with our overall compliance with personal data
protection requirements or even require us to discontinue using certain tools that are relevant to our business. Any
non-compliance, including as a result of our use of Google Analytics and Amazon Web Services, could result in
potentially significant regulatory and/or governmental investigations and/or actions, litigation, fines, sanctions,
and damage to our reputation. In this context, uncertainty remains as it pertains to transfers of personal data from
the EEA to the United States and certain other “non-adequate” jurisdictions. The EU-U.S. Data Privacy
Framework (“EU-U.S. DPF”) was developed to facilitate transatlantic commerce by providing U.S. organizations
with reliable mechanisms for personal data transfers to the United States from the EU / EEA that were consistent
with EU data privacy laws. The EU-U.S. DPF aims to rectify the deficiencies identified by the CJEU when it
invalidated its predecessor (the “Privacy Shield”) in the “Schrems II” ruling, by introducing enhanced safeguards
and more stringent requirements to curtail U.S. surveillance access to EU residents’ data. However, it is likely
that the EU-U.S. DPF will be challenged before the CJEU, and potentially struck, resulting in further changes to
the data privacy background in the context of transfer of personal data from EU countries. Against this
background, the European Commission successfully concluded its review of 11 existing adequacy decisions
adopted under the EU data protection legislation that preceded the GDPR on January 15, 2024. The European
Commission found that personal data transferred from the EU to Andorra, Argentina, Canada, Faroe Islands,
Guernsey, the Isle of Man, Israel, Jersey, New Zealand, Switzerland and Uruguay, continues to benefit from
adequate data protection safeguards. Therefore, the adequacy decisions adopted for these eleven countries and
territories remain in place and data can continue to flow freely to these jurisdictions. However, while the European
Commission adopted an adequacy decision for the U.K. on June 28, 2021, allowing the continued flow of personal
data from the EEA to the U.K., this decision will automatically expire in June 2025 unless the European
Commission re-assesses and renews or extends it. The decision will be regularly reviewed by the European
Commission going forward and may be revoked if the U.K. diverges from its current data protection laws and the
European Commission deems the U.K. to no longer provide adequate protection of personal data. Were the EUU.S. DPF be declared invalid following judicial review by the CJEU, the U.K.’s adequacy decision not be renewed
or extended or any other third-parties or territories be deemed to have non-adequate data protection measures
under “Schrems II” or otherwise, we may be required to make further modifications to our practices and policies,
potentially involving significant additional costs.

Furthermore, existing, and future decisions by local governmental regulators may also impact the application of
the GDPR. For example, in January 2022, the Austrian Data Protection Authority issued a decision that a
company’s use of Google Analytics contravenes the GDPR with regard to potential data transfers to the
US. Complying with such decisions could impose further costs on us and limit our ability to use data analytics
software to support our operations.

Additionally, significant modifications in other data protection laws or regulations in countries in which we
operate may consequently lead to us incurring higher costs or having to change our business practices. Compliance
will become more complex and involve higher costs and the increasing risk of noncompliance may give rise to

Unauthorized data disclosure could occur through cyber security breaches as a result of human error, external

**_Our user metrics and other estimates are subject to inherent challenges in measurement, and inaccuracies in_**
**_those metrics could have an adverse impact on our business, results of operations, and financial condition._**

We regularly review metrics, including but not limited to active users, new customers and average order value,
frequency, and quantity, to evaluate growth trends, measure our performance, and make strategic decisions. These
metrics are calculated using internal systems and tools that are not independently verified by any third party and
the metrics have not been validated by an independent third party. Our internal systems and tools have a number
of limitations, and our methodologies for tracking these metrics may change over time, which could result in
unexpected changes to our metrics, including the metrics we publicly disclose on an ongoing basis. If the internal
systems and tools we use to track these metrics undercount or over count performance or contain algorithmic or
other technical errors, the data we present may not be accurate. While these numbers are based on what we believe
to be reasonable estimates of our user base for the applicable period of measurement, there are inherent challenges
in measuring how our platform is used. Errors or inaccuracies in our metrics or data could result in incorrect
business decisions and inefficiencies.

For example, as it pertains to our active users metric, there are individuals who have multiple accounts on our
platform. A user is separately identified on our platform by a unique e-mail address; therefore, a single person
with multiple registered accounts could be counted as multiple distinct users for purposes of this metric. If a
significant understatement or overstatement of active users were to occur, we may expend resources to implement
unnecessary business measures or fail to take required actions to attract enough users to satisfy our growth
strategies.

Further, certain other information we collect from users, including personal data, is self-reported and may differ
from actual data. For example, age and other demographic information may be inaccurate if our users provide us
with incorrect or incomplete information regarding their age or other attributes or choose not to report this
information. If there were material inaccuracies in our user demographic metrics, it would result in the inefficient
allocation of our marketing budget or resources, which could seriously harm our business.

**_Changes in customer return rates might increase our costs and harm our business._**

We have established return policies that permit our customers to return products within designated timeframes
ranging from 14 to 30 days, depending on their membership status (30 days for Diamond customers, 21 days for
Gold and 14 days for all others). Granting return rights is an important element for converting app and website
visitors into customers, by providing our customers with the certainty that they will only be required to pay for
those products that they want to keep. Moreover, we have a customer-friendly returns policy. It is possible that,
in the future, a growing number of customers may abuse our returns policy and, for example, buy merchandise
just to wear it once at a party and then return it, claiming it had arrived used. We generally experience a higher
return rate from customers who pay for our merchandise with invoices (in lieu of using standard payment
platforms). Our failure to prevent abuse of our returns policy or to otherwise manage our returns policy effectively
could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial position.

Certain of our online customers, including online customers in Germany, have statutory rights with respect to the
return of merchandise. We have in the past, and may in the future, experience a significant increase in returns—
for example, due to customer dissatisfaction with our products or customer service, changes in customer behavior,
decrease in purchasing power due to inflationary pressures or the abuse of our liberal return policy by persons not
actually willing to purchase our products. In these cases, we incur costs associated with returned goods, including
costs associated with return processing and delivery, but may not be able to generate revenue from returned
merchandise or, alternatively, if we generate revenue, the proceeds may not cover all costs incurred. In addition,

-----

we bear the risk for damage or loss of the returned merchandise. Thus, any increase in returns would potentially
increase our costs without a proportionate increase in revenue.

Continued growth is likely to increase the absolute number of returns, which may force us to allocate additional
resources to the handling of such returns, may further complicate our operations and heighten the impact of the
abovementioned risks associated to return volumes. Furthermore, any modifications to our return policies may
result in customer dissatisfaction, which could harm our reputation, or lead to an increase in the number of returns,
which could adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations.

**_Environmental, social and governance matters may impact our business and reputation._**

There has been increased focus, by consumers, investors, employees, and other stakeholders, as well as by
governmental and non-governmental organizations, on environmental, social and governance matters (“ESG”)
generally and regarding the fashion industry specifically.

Any failure by us to meet our ESG commitments or targets, or loss of confidence, or inability to meet expectations
with our ESG commitments on the part of customers, investors, employees, brand partners, and other stakeholders
as it relates to our ESG initiatives could negatively impact our brand, our brand partner relationships, and the
demand for our offerings. These impacts could be difficult and costly to overcome, even if such concerns were
based on inaccurate or misleading information. Furthermore, while we believe we have an inherently sustainable
business model (as most of the articles we sell are overstock and our model aims to ensure that every piece of
fashion that has been produced and is fit-to-wear finds an owner), it is possible that our model will not be perceived
as sustainable by customers, investors, employees, brand partners, and other stakeholders. If we fail, or are
perceived to fail, to meet applicable standards or expectations with respect to ESG issues, including the
expectations we set for ourselves, or if stakeholders’ perceptions of the sustainability of our model are negative,
this could also negatively impact our business and reputation as a result of negative allegations or litigation and
our business, financial condition and results of operations could be adversely impacted. For example, as
stakeholder perceptions of sustainability continue to evolve, there have been increasing allegations of
greenwashing against companies making significant ESG claims due to a variety of perceived deficiencies in
performance. Furthermore, advertising (including ESG advertising) to consumers is subject to a complex
legislative and regulatory landscape which, in our case, includes, at a transnational level, the European Green Deal
and, at a local level, Germany’s harmonized Law against Unfair Competition (Gesetz gegen den unlauteren
_Wettbewerb; “UWG”), with regulatory agencies and competition and consumer protection organizations_
increasingly pursuing litigation against companies deemed to incur in greenwashing. For example, the German
Centre for Protection against Unfair Competition (Wettbewerbszentrale) has successfully litigated several
proceedings on the basis that companies have made misleading statements as to their “environmentally neutral”
status. These proceedings have resulted in the development of strict court standards which may in the future be
applied to climate-related claims in addition to environmental neutrality. As part of the European Green Deal, an
EU-wide set of rules regarding green claims vis-à-vis consumers has been, or is close to being adopted in the form
of Directive (EU) 2024/825 as regards empowering consumers for the green transition and of the draft Directive
on substantiation and communication of explicit environmental claims (Green Claims Directive). Current, and
any future, legal developments in this area may therefore result in our increased exposure to litigation and any
associated liability, as well as to authority orders and significant administrative fines, whether in the context of
misleading ESG advertising or otherwise, which could in turn affect our reputation and negatively impact our
results of operations and financial prospects.

In addition, achieving our ESG initiatives and/or meeting respective legal requirements may result in increased
costs in our supply chain, fulfillment, and/or corporate business operations. Standards regarding environmental,
social, and governance initiatives could change and become more onerous for both for us and our third-party brand
partners to meet successfully. For example, in January 2023, the European Union’s Corporate Sustainability
Reporting Directive (“CSRD”) took effect. This directive, as implemented by forthcoming European Union
Member State legislation, will result in various sustainability disclosures being provided by various entities, on a
phased basis, with the first entities in scope from January 1, 2024, reporting in 2025. We are considered a large
undertaking under CSRD and are, therefore, required to report on certain sustainability requirements for the fiscal
year ending December 31, 2025. We expect that the significant new sustainability disclosures under the CSRD
will impact us directly and indirectly and result in increased costs and potentially impact our business or reputation
to the extent our disclosures are deemed inadequate or false and misleading. In addition, the Corporate
Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (“CSDDD”) has been formally adopted by the European Parliament on
April 24, 2024, and by the Council of the European Union on May 24, 2024. Upon publication in the Official
Journal of the European Union, the CSDDD will enter into force on the twentieth day following its publication.
The directive aims at providing a harmonized legal framework for sustainability considerations in the supply chain

42


-----

of European companies. Among other things, it will establish a corporate due diligence duty, which is aimed at
ending, preventing, mitigating, and accounting for negative human rights and environmental impacts in a
company’s own operations, including subsidiaries, and their value chains. The CSDDD will be rolled out in
phases, depending on the number of employees and net worldwide turnover. Five years after entry into force of
the directive, it will apply to companies that had more than 1,000 employees and a net worldwide turnover above
€450 million in the last fiscal year. The CSDDD still needs to be transposed into national law of the EU Member
States. As a result, there remains uncertainty as to the potential impact of this new regime on us. For example, we
expect that the transposition of the CSDDD into German law will affect the German Supply Chain Due Diligence
Act (Lieferkettensorgfaltspflichtengesetz) (“LkSG”), which regulates certain due diligence obligations for
companies in the supply chain and entered into force on January 1, 2023 (and became applicable to us on January
1, 2024). In light thereof, among other measures, we recently implemented a supplier code of conduct that seeks
to comply with the mandates of the LkSG we may be subject to additional compliance costs and dedication of
resources in the future to the extent we have to modify our supplier code of conduct, our agreements with suppliers
and any related internal controls, procedures and IT tools to fully align with the requirements of the CSDDD.
Additionally, on June 29, 2023, the EU Deforestation Regulation (“EUDR”) came into force, which places
obligations on companies trading in cattle, cocoa, coffee, oil palm, rubber, soya and wood, as well as many
products derived from these commodities, to conduct extensive diligence on the value chain to ensure the goods
do not result from recent deforestation, forest degradation or breaches of local environmental and social laws
starting on December 30, 2024. To the extent that we trade in products covered by the EUDR, such as products
containing wood, we may be required to further update our internal controls on our value chain, including our
supplier code of conduct and our agreements with suppliers to ensure compliance. Furthermore, there is a risk that
we will not be able to market and sell the affected products should we fail to comply with the requirements of the
EUDR by December 31, 2024. Although we believe that the impact of this risk on our Group is limited, we cannot
guarantee that any amendments to the provision or the promulgation of other, similar provisions, will not have a
material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

A variety of organizations measure the performance of companies on such ESG topics, and the results of these
assessments are widely publicized. In addition, investment in funds that specialize in companies that perform well
in such assessments are increasingly popular, and major institutional investors have publicly emphasized the
importance of such ESG measures to their investment decisions. Topics taken into account in such assessments
include, among others, a company’s efforts and impacts on climate change and human rights, ethics and
compliance with law and the role of a company’s board of directors in supervising various sustainability issues.
In light of investors’ increased focus on ESG matters, there can be no certainty that we will manage such issues
successfully, or that we will successfully meet society’s and investors’ ESG expectations or achieve our financial
goals. As part of our commitment to ESG matters, we are planning to introduce specific, quantifiable key
performance indicators. If we fail to meet the targets of these or other key performance indicators, we may suffer
reputational damage, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business and financial condition.

**_Dissatisfaction with our convenience proposition could negatively affect our customer retention and the_**
**_implementation of our growth strategy._**

A satisfied, loyal customer base is crucial for our ongoing expansion. Based on our members-only business model,
attracting new customers depends in part on word-of-mouth and the recommendations of existing customers to
expand our customer base. We therefore must ensure that existing customers are satisfied with our convenience
proposition, including content creation, usability of our online platform and app, check-out process, payment
options, packaging and shipping and customer service, so that those customers continue to recommend us. Should
our efforts to satisfy existing customers be unsuccessful, we may fail to continue expanding our business or may
be obliged to incur significant marketing and development expenditure to attract new customers.

For example, reliable customer support is vital to ensure that customer complaints are processed within
appropriate timeframes and under satisfactory conditions. Providing this support requires that our customer
support personnel have fashion, retail, technical, and other necessary knowledge and expertise, making it difficult
for us to hire qualified personnel and scale our support operations. The demand on our customer service
organization will increase as we expand our business and pursue new customers, and such increased support could
require us to devote significant development services and support personnel to our customer service teams, which
could strain our team and infrastructure and reduce our profit margins. Any absence of a response or an
unsatisfactory response to customer queries or complaints, whether founded or perceived as such, may have a
detrimental impact on customer loyalty and satisfaction as well as our reputation, particularly if customers make
negative comments on blogs, social media, or through online ratings and reviews. We may not be able to verify
or adequately respond to such negative comments, ratings or reviews. An inability to retain customers and earn

-----

their loyalty, or to identify, follow up and respond to customer complaints and online comments due to customer
service failings, may have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are exposed to risks associated to the payment options we offer._**

We currently offer different payment methods tailored to meet our customers’ payment preferences, including
cards, PayPal and purchase by invoice. We face the risk of operational failures during the check-out process in
our e-commerce platform as well as our retail stores relating to the complexity of certain payment methods. Such
difficulties could adversely affect our conversion rate which is the proportion of site visitors that actually complete
the purchasing process. We may also become subject to additional or changing regulations regarding certain
payment methods, such as the operating rules and certification requirements of payment scheme associations and
rules governing electronic funds transfers, which apply to payment cards, whether in general or in a particular
country in which we operate. We may also become subject to more stringent or complex compliance requirements,
for example with respect to our vouchers. For the processing of all our current payment methods we pay different
fees to our payment method providers. It is possible that some of these fees would increase over time, causing our
expenses to rise. In the case of invoice payments, even though the default risk currently lies with our service
provider, a high non-payment rate will lead to either increased costs for us or a lowered acceptance rate for
customers using this payment method. Furthermore, different payment options have different costs to us (e.g.,
PayPal is much more expensive than purchase by invoice) and should customers shift their preferences in favor
of the more expensive payment methods, then our expenses would rise accordingly.

Furthermore, various types of fraud committed through payments may increase our overall cost. These types of
fraud vary, and range from account take-overs, usage of stolen credit cards, fake identities, fake bank accounts, to
“almost legal fraud” like voucher abusing or the creation of multiple accounts to take advantage of our loyalty
system. In case of excessive fraud events relating to credit card transactions, in addition to the direct losses, we
could enter the card schemes’ chargeback monitoring programs, where we could incur extra fees and even lose
the right to accept cards altogether.

For online payments, primary liability for fraud generally lies with the party with the lowest security standards,
which, in most cases, is the merchant. While strong authentication methods such as two-factor authentication, can
help us alleviate some of this risk, we consciously elect to forego the strongest authentication methods because
the added hurdle for the customer would detract from a seamless customer experience. Further, some payment
methods, such as unsecured direct debits, have by design no authorization mechanism and thus we bear significant
risk. Failure to adequately balance a seamless and streamlined customer experience with adequate security and
anti-fraud protections could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position and results of
operations.

**_We might be exposed to tax risks or tax liabilities resulting from deviating interpretations of applicable tax laws_**
**_or tax audits or a challenge of the transfer pricing model by the tax authorities._**

We are subject to routine tax field audit (Außenprüfung) by local tax authorities (i.e., _Finanzamt Abt._
_Körperschaften) in Munich. This audit for the years 2018 to 2021 commenced in November 2023 by introducing_
a catalog of questions. The audit includes all German entities of the BestSecret Group. Furthermore, tax audits for
periods or jurisdictions not yet subject to a tax audit may exceed the taxes already paid by us or reflected in our
Consolidated Financial Statements. As a result, we may be required to make additional tax payments with respect
to previous periods. Moreover, the competent tax authorities could revise their original tax assessments. Any tax
assessments that deviate from our expectations could lead to an increase in our tax burden. In addition, we may
be required to pay interest on these additional taxes as well as late filing penalties. Furthermore, we have carried
out reorganizations of the Group structure, and there is a risk that any such restructuring could attract additional
tax scrutiny or result in a tax leakage despite our best efforts to avoid such negative tax consequences (e.g.,
obtaining tax advisory services by reputable consultants who confirmed the tax neutrality of the Group structure
reorganizations).

Due to our operations in various jurisdictions, such as Germany, Austria, Switzerland, France, Sweden, the
Netherlands, Poland and Spain, we are exposed to various tax risks, including risks based on transfer pricing rules
which apply to cross-border business relationships, for example, purchase, logistics, distribution or commission
agreements or other arrangements. Pursuant to such transfer pricing rules, related enterprises are required to
conduct any inter-company transactions on terms which would also apply among unrelated third parties
concluding comparable agreements (so-called “arm’s length principle”) and to sufficiently document the relevant
transactions. One or more tax authorities might not agree with, and thus challenge the cross-jurisdictional transfer
pricing model we implemented. For example, our documentation may be considered to be insufficient by the

44


-----

relevant tax authorities or transfer prices may be considered to be inadequate or inadequately justified. This may
result in double taxation in two or more jurisdictions and penalties. Moreover, transfer pricing risks may increase
in the future in case our intra-group cross-border business grows or changes or if tax authorities change their
interpretation of applicable transfer pricing rules.

Furthermore, the documentation obligations under applicable value-added tax (“VAT”) and VAT-related laws are
considerable. Overall, it cannot be ruled out that the competent tax authorities may interpret the tax law (now or
in the future) in a way that suggests that we may not fully comply, or, as the case may be, may have not fully
complied with applicable VAT regulations throughout all phases of their development. Any additional tax
payments could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

**_Application of international tax laws on our international operations may expose us to potentially adverse tax_**
**_consequences._**

As a result of our international operations and business, we are subject to tax laws in several jurisdictions, in
particular, Germany, Austria, Switzerland, France, Sweden, the Netherlands, Poland and Spain. We are also
subject to transfer pricing laws, including those relating to the flow of funds among our companies pursuant to,
for example, purchase, logistics, distribution or commission agreements or other arrangements. Adverse
developments in the tax laws or regulations in these jurisdictions, or any change in position by the relevant
authority regarding the application, administration or interpretation of tax laws or regulations in any applicable
jurisdiction, could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We depend on qualified personnel, including certain key personnel such as our senior management, as well_**
**_as, our external employees, and may not be able to retain or replace such personnel._**

Our success and future growth depend significantly on the performance of our senior management and qualified
personnel in certain functions, including but not limited to IT, tech, data, purchasing and logistics as well as
merchandising. In addition, a certain proportion of our personnel working on technology related matters are
classed as external employees. In the event of departure of one or more of these key and qualified personnel, we
may not be able to replace them quickly, which could affect our operational performance. More generally, we
may be unable to recruit new personnel whose skills and industry experience are equivalent to those of our key
and qualified personnel or could fail to attract and retain experienced personnel in the future. In addition, should
our executives or key employees join a competitor or create a competing business, it could have a negative impact
on our operations. Furthermore, many of our procurement employees have good relationships with brand partners,
many of which have developed over decades. If we are not able to retain these employees, we may fail to maintain
or further develop these relationships with brand partners.

If we fail to attract, train, motivate or retain skilled personnel or if our operations are affected over a longer period
of time by labor disputes or if we are forced to enter into a collective bargaining agreement at unfavorable terms,
this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, and our reputation.

**_We are exposed to the risk of rising labor costs as well as work stoppages, strikes or other collective actions._**

Personnel expenses represent a significant part of our cost base. We may face considerable wage increases in the
future, for example in connection with statutory minimum wages, current inflation dynamics or otherwise as a
result of generally rising wages. If we are not successful in limiting such increases in personnel costs, or if cost
increases cannot be passed on to our customers, this may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
position and results of operations.

Some of our subsidiaries are bound by collective bargaining agreements (Tarifverträge) or are members of an
employer association (Arbeitgeberverband). For example, Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH are
our only Group companies that are members of an employers’ association, although such membership does not
entail the application of collective bargaining agreements (OT Mitgliedschaft). Additionally, industry-wide
collective bargaining agreements apply in Austria, Italy and Spain. For example, due to mandatory membership
in the Austrian Chamber of Commerce (Wirtschaftskammer), Best Secret Retail Wien GmbH is bound by two
collective bargaining agreements for employees and apprentices in commercial operations. As a result, there can
be no assurance that labor disputes, work stoppages, strikes or similar actions will not occur in the future which
might urge us to adopt or negotiate further collective bargaining agreements. Any material disagreements between
us and our employees could disrupt our operations, lead to a loss in revenue and customers and increase our
operating costs. In addition, there is no guarantee that collective bargaining would be possible on terms that are
satisfactory to us. See—“Our Business—Employees.”

Any deterioration of such relationships in the future or any material work stoppages, strikes or other types of

**_We face certain risks in relation to future acquisitions._**

We may, from time to time, evaluate certain acquisition opportunities, including acquiring new online fashion
retailers. For example, in 2016 we acquired Swiss Online Shopping AG as part of our expansion into Switzerland,
which, at the time of acquisition and during the following months, was generating losses. There can be no
assurance that we will be able to identify suitable targets and consummate an acquisition on favorable terms or at
all. It is also possible that not all material risks in connection with acquisitions will be identified in the due
diligence process and that such risks will not be taken into account in the decision-making process or the respective
agreements to a sufficient level or at all. In addition, future acquisitions may also entail financial and tax
restructuring measures which, even if designed with the aim of achieving a tax-efficient structure, may expose us
to risks, e.g., if the tax authorities were to challenge any of the implemented measures.

Upon making acquisitions, our performance will depend, in part, on our ability to successfully integrate the
acquired businesses in an efficient manner. Such integration may be a complex, time-consuming and expensive
process and will likely involve a number of risks, including the costs and expenses associated with unexpected
difficulties, initial or ongoing losses in periods following the acquisition, the diversion of management’s attention
from our daily operations, additional demands on management related to the increase in the size and scope of our
operations following an acquisition and any undisclosed liabilities of an acquired company. Even if we are able
to successfully integrate newly-acquired businesses, this integration may not result in the realization of the
synergies, cost savings, revenue and cash flow enhancements, operational efficiencies and other benefits that we
expect. We may also incur unexpected liabilities in connection with such acquisitions. If these liabilities are
significant or if we fail to integrate a new acquisition effectively, this could have a material adverse impact on our
business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We are subject to a variety of regulations, including but not limited to laws governing data protection, telemedia_**

**_laws, and future regulations might impose additional requirements and other obligations on our business._**

We are, or in the future may be, subject to a number of laws and regulations applicable to e-commerce or fashion,

These laws and regulations cover, among other things, data protection, telemedia services, consumer protection,

may impede the growth and availability of the internet and online services, inhibit our ability to grow our business,

**_Climate change and related regulatory responses as well as customer awareness may adversely impact our_**
**_business._**

There is increasing concern that a gradual increase in global average temperatures due to increased concentration
of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases in the atmosphere will cause significant changes in weather patterns
around the globe and an increase in the frequency and severity of natural disasters. Changes in weather patterns
and an increased frequency, intensity and duration of extreme weather conditions could, among other things,
adversely impact our suppliers’ supply chain operations, increase the cost of our suppliers’ products, and impact
the types of products that customers purchase. As a result, the effects of climate change could have an adverse
impact on our business and results of operations.

In many countries, governmental bodies are increasingly enacting legislation and regulations in response to the
potential impacts of climate change. These laws have the potential to impact our operations indirectly as a result
of required compliance by our suppliers and the manufacturers of their products. In addition, we are active in an
industry that is not considered to be environmentally sustainable, and we depend on shipping logistics, which lead
to a high emission of carbon dioxide. As a result, our customers might refuse to acquire merchandise from us and
turn to more sustainable competitors or reduce or refrain from acquiring fashion products. If we take steps to
voluntarily mitigate our impact on climate change, we may experience increases in energy and transportation
costs, capital expenditures or insurance premiums and deductibles. Inconsistency of legislation and regulations
among jurisdictions may also affect the costs of compliance with such laws and regulations. Any assessment of
the potential impact of future climate change legislation, regulations, or industry standards, as well as any
international treaties and accords, is uncertain given the wide scope of potential regulatory change in the countries
in which we operate or conduct business. In addition, apart from legislative developments we see a growing risk
stemming from emerging climate change litigation globally. The rise of so-called “strategic litigation networks”
that are targeting specific industries with particular forms of litigation while forum shopping in various
jurisdictions constitutes a significant risk for our business that is difficult to assess.

**_Third parties might accuse us of infringing their intellectual property rights._**

The e-commerce industry, as well as the fashion industry in general, is characterized by vigorous protection for
and pursuit of intellectual property rights. We have in the past been, and in the future may be, subject to claims
and allegations of infringement of third parties’ intellectual property rights. Brand and content owners and other
proprietary rights owners have actively asserted their purported rights against online companies, including the
Group. In particular, we have in the past received, and in future may receive, cease-and-desist letters from fashion
brands requesting that we cease importing merchandise that allegedly infringes upon their intellectual property.
Infringement of third parties’ intellectual property rights could subject us to significant liability for damages. Such
claims may in the future result, and have in the past resulted, in our goods being seized by customs authorities as
part of investigations into intellectual property infringement claims. The costs of defending against such actions
can be high, and there is no guarantee that such defenses will be successful. Such actions could also result in the
diversion of our management’s time and attention. Moreover, infringement of third parties’ intellectual property
rights may result in limitations on our ability to use the intellectual property or in the prohibition of using the
intellectual property at all, subject to the respective claims, unless we are able to enter into agreements with the
intellectual property owners. Furthermore, as our business expands and the number of competitors in our market
increases, infringement claims against us could increase in number and significance. In addition to litigation from
rights owners, we may be subject to regulatory, civil or criminal proceedings and penalties if governmental
authorities believe we have aided and abetted in the sale of counterfeit or other unlawful products. Such claims,
whether or not meritorious, could result in significant additional expenses, redirect management attention, and
have an adverse effect on our reputation as well as on our financial condition.

Legal claims regarding intellectual property rights are subject to inherent uncertainties due to the complex issues
involved, and we cannot be certain that we will be successful in defending ourselves against such claims. Many
potential litigants have the ability to dedicate substantially greater resources than we do to the enforcement of
intellectual property rights and defense of claims that may be brought against them. If successful, a claimant could
secure a judgment against us for substantial damages or prevent us from conducting our business as we have
historically done so or may desire to do so in the future. We could also be required to seek authorization or make
payments in order to use of the intellectual property we need to conduct our business, which we may not be able
to achieve on commercially acceptable terms or at all. Alternatively, we may be forced to develop non-infringing
intellectual property on a proprietary basis, which could be expensive and/or unsuccessful. We use third-party
software on the basis of software license agreements. We may not have sufficient licenses to cover the actual
scope of use of such software in our business operations, which may require us to pay compensation to, and to
acquire further licenses from, the owners of the rights in the relevant software. In addition, we may be required to
obtain further licenses to enhance our business operations, and we may also be required to change the current
software providers and enter into agreements with new software providers with less favorable terms. This may
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Currency volatility may materially adversely affect our business._**

We operate our business in 27 European countries, several of which use currencies other than the euro, and source
our products from various international brand partners, which exposes us to fluctuations between the euro, our
reporting currency, and other currencies, in particular the Polish złoty. In addition, we have commenced the
operation of our second fulfillment center in Suchelów, Poland. We anticipate that this new fulfillment center will
be fully scaled up over the next few years. Once the fulfillment center in Poland achieves fully scaled operations,
we will be increasingly exposed to currency risk. Such risks arise due to fluctuations or devaluations of currencies,
inflation and foreign exchange controls or governmental measures that impact our ability to convert currencies.
In addition, where parts of the cost of sales are not denominated in the same currency of such sales, translation
risks arise. If the euro gains in strength, the value of our foreign sales will fall, and if the euro weakens, our costs
for foreign imports will rise.

We carry insurance of various types, including general business interruption and third-party liability, property

related to the health and safety of our employees and contractors as well as other workplace safety risks. As our
uniform health and safety standards are mainly issued to our German facilities, each region is working under
different standards and are at varying stages of maturity and there exists only limited control in this space.
Additionally, documentation and record keeping of safety records may prove insufficient to substantiate to
regulators that our health and safety systems are operating effectively. If staff and contractors get injured during

the course of their duties we may, among other things, face fines and penalties from regulators as well as damage
to our reputation.

We are furthermore exposed to risks due to external factors beyond our control, including, but not limited to,

We may not always be able to accurately foresee all situations that should otherwise be covered by the terms of
our insurance policies and, as a result, we may not be covered by insurance in specific instances. While we believe

**_Many of our suppliers rely on credit insurance to protect their receivables, and any changes to, or slow_**
**_adjustments or withdrawals of, such credit insurance might cause suppliers to seek to reduce their credit_**
**_exposure to us._**

We believe that many of our suppliers have traditionally taken out credit insurance to protect their receivables
against the risk of bad debt, insolvency or protracted default of their buyers, including us. Credit levels available
to us from our suppliers remain dependent on the general economic environment and our financial position. If
there is a significant decrease in the availability of credit insurance to our suppliers, or if an increase in credit
levels is administered too slowly or such insurance is withdrawn in its entirety, and if such suppliers are unwilling
or unable to take credit risk themselves or find alternative credit sources, they may choose to reduce their credit
exposure to us, for example by seeking to change their credit terms vis-à-vis our Group. Any such actions could
have a material adverse effect on our cash position, lead to an increase in our indebtedness or have a negative
impact on our product offerings and, thus, on our sales. This could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial position and results of operations.

**_We might be exposed to tax risks or tax liabilities resulting from adverse amendments to current legislation,_**
**_including developments in the tax treatment of companies engaged in e-commerce in the jurisdictions in which_**
**_we operate, that could adversely affect the commercial use of our sites and our financial results._**

Our business is subject to the general tax environment in the countries in which we operate, such as Germany,
Austria, Switzerland, France, Sweden, the Netherlands, Poland and Spain. Changes in tax legislation,
administrative practice or case law or treatments of tax facts by the relevant tax authorities which deviate from
our assessments — and might be applied retroactively — could result in a higher tax burden. The realization of
any of these risks, alone or in combination, may have adverse effects on our business, financial condition and
results of operations.

In particular, developments in tax law, regulation, or case law, with regards to transnational e-commerce activities
could affect our tax burden. Since 2017, the G20/OECD Inclusive Framework has been working on addressing
the tax challenges arising from the digitalization of the economy and agreed on a two-pillar tax approach with
pillar one referring to the re-allocation of taxing rights, addressing issues such as where tax should be paid and on
what basis (i.e., where sustained and significant business is conducted, regardless of a physical presence), and
pillar two ensuring a minimum tax to be paid by multinational enterprises. In Germany, Pillar Two has been
implemented by the Minimum Taxation Act (Gesetz zur Gewährleistung einer globalen Mindestbesteuerung für
_Unternehmensgruppen (Mindeststeuergesetz – MinStG)). The new law came into force on December 28, 2023_
and implements Council Directive (EU) 2022/2523 (“Pillar Two Directive”). The new law will generally apply
to fiscal years beginning after December 30, 2023. Therefore, although we currently do not expect any impact to
our tax obligations derived from Pillar One and Pillar Two (including the Minimum Taxation Act), the
implementation of Pillar One and Pillar Two (including the Minimum Taxation Act) could have adverse effects
for us in the future as we are a digital and multinational enterprise.

49


-----

Changes in tax treatment of companies engaged in e-commerce in the jurisdictions in which we operate could
adversely affect the commercial use of our sites and our financial results. For example, some jurisdictions in which
we operate our business (e.g., Italy) have introduced new local taxes on transnational e-commerce activities
(“digital services taxes” or “DST”). These DST generally aim at securing taxation rights of the jurisdiction for
the revenue / profit generated by the transnational e-commerce activities with customers who are resident in this
specific jurisdiction. We have established a process to assess on a regular (i.e., quarterly) basis whether our
revenue / profit is subject to these DST. In the context of the G20/OECD Inclusive Framework, certain states
generally agreed upon mitigating their existing DST and abstaining from introducing new DST before the earlier
of December 31, 2023, or the date Pillar One rules become effective, but there remains a general risk that new
local DST will be introduced or that the existing DST will be applied differently with the result that this could
adversely affect our tax liability. We cannot predict the effect of current attempts to impose sales, income or other
taxes on e-commerce. New or revised taxes – e.g., sales taxes, VAT and similar taxes – could increase the cost of
doing business online and decrease the attractiveness of advertising and selling products over the internet. New
taxes could also lead to increases in internal costs necessary to capture data and collect and remit taxes to the
relevant tax authorities which could adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of operation.

Moreover, legislators and tax authorities may change territoriality rules or their interpretation for the application
of VAT on cross-border services, which may lead to additional payments for past and future periods. In addition,
court decisions are sometimes ignored by competent tax authorities or overruled by higher courts, which could
lead to higher legal and tax advisory costs and create uncertainty. New taxes could also result in additional costs
necessary to collect the data required to assess these taxes and to remit them to the relevant tax authorities which
could adversely affect our business, financial condition, and results of operation.

**_Our intangible assets, such as goodwill and trademarks, are subject to the risk of impairment._**

Our intangible assets, primarily consisting of goodwill, customer relationships, trademarks, licenses and software,
are regularly reviewed on the basis of certain assumptions, including cash-flow and growth rate estimates. For
example, the permanent closure of our stationary store in Frankfurt in July 2021 led to a full impairment of the
respective customer base in the amount of €5.0 million. As of March 31, 2024, our goodwill amounted to
€203.5 million and our other intangible assets amounted to €230.4 million. Any changes to the assumptions, in
particular negative revenue trends, underlying the valuation of our intangible assets could increase the risk of
impairment.
