**Overview**

We are one of Europe’s leading online destinations for premium and luxury off-price fashion. With a focus on
international premium and luxury brands, we offer our customers in 27 countries across Europe a standing
assortment of highly desirable fashion at exclusive prices in a premium shopping environment. At the same time,
we enable our brand partners to clear overstock at scale with minimum visibility and strong brand equity
protection. The success of our unique business model is based on its closed character with an invitation-only
customer membership, viral customer growth leading to unparalleled marketing efficiency, longstanding brand

72


-----

partner and customer relationships, a tech-focused mindset, and its inherent contribution to more sustainability in
the fashion industry. We have a strong track record of profitable growth over many years. For the years ended
December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated revenue of €942.9
million, €1,051.0 million, €1,226.0 million and €1,290.6 million, respectively, an Adjusted EBITDA Before Run
Rate Cost Synergies of €138.7 million, €132.5 million, €165.8 million and €183.0 million, respectively, and an
Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate Cost Synergies Margin of 14.7%, 12.6%, 13.5% and 14.2%, respectively.
Our revenue and Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA grew from €1,077.8 million and €143.6 million, respectively, in
the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 to €1,290.6 million and €200.9 million in the twelve months ended
March 31, 2024, representing increases over 20% and 40%, respectively, over the same period. Our online revenue
accounted for 93.0%, 91.2%, 91.9% and 92.1% of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022
and 2023 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, respectively (with a CAGR of 13.3% from the year ended
December 31, 2021 to the year ended December 31, 2023). While 59.0% of our revenue for the twelve months
ended March 31, 2024 (€762.0 million) was generated in Germany, our international business outside of Germany
continues to gain importance relative to our Germany business and experienced strong revenue growth from
€384.3 million (35.7% of revenue) in the twelve months ended March 31, 2023 to €528.5 million (41% of revenue)
in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, and from €267.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to
€489.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, representing a CAGR of 35.2% over the same period.

**Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations**

Our results of operations and the operating metrics discussed in this section have been, and may continue to be,
affected by the key factors set forth below as well as certain historical and future events and actions. As many of
these factors are beyond our control and certain of these factors have historically been volatile, past performance
will not necessarily be indicative of future performance and it is difficult to predict future performance with any
degree of certainty. See “Risk Factors.” We consider the following factors to be the principal drivers of our results
of operations.

**_Growth of the European online fashion market and the off-price sector_**

Our addressable market is currently experiencing favorable structural trends. We operate in the European online
off-price fashion market for mid-market to luxury brands, which is the fastest growing segment of the fashion
market. The total mid-market to luxury European fashion market (excluding the U.K., Turkey and Russia)
amounted to €247 billion in revenue (of which €49 billion correspond to the off-price market) in the year ended
December 31, 2023 based on analysis prepared by a leading international strategy consultancy firm and the
Company. We operate in the online off-price market, which amounted to €20 billion in revenue across Europe
(excluding the U.K., Turkey and Russia) in the year ended December 31, 2023 and is expected to grow at a CAGR
of 10% from 2023 to 2028 based on the analysis prepared by a leading international strategy consultancy firm and
the Company.

In recent years, we have transformed into a primarily online platform for off-price premium products. Revenue
from our online operations increased by nearly 20% between the years ended December 31, 2021 and
December 31, 2023 as a result of continued customer growth and NMV retention among our existing active online
customers. Our online revenue represented 91.9% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023, as
compared to 93.0% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2021. From January 1, 2021 to
December 31, 2023, our number of active online customers increased at a CAGR of 27.4%. We plan to maintain
a limited physical presence of premium and outlet stores in strategic locations designed primarily to support our
online platform, with offline revenue expected to remain a limited percentage of our total revenue.

While we believe that our business model is resilient to minor general economic effects, and that off-price is
typically more resilient relative to the rest of the fashion market during economic downturns, it is possible that
unfavorable macroeconomic events in Germany, and more broadly in Europe, may have a negative effect on the
growth of the European online fashion market and impact our customers and our results of operations. These
include factors that may affect consumer spending such as unemployment levels, inflation, wage rates, availability
of consumer credit and consumer confidence. For example, recent geopolitical tensions resulting from the Russian
invasion of Ukraine and the military conflict between Israel and Hamas have destabilized the global economy and
will potentially have a wide range of supply chain implications, including increases in the costs of merchandise
and disruption in freight transport.

73


-----

**_Our ability to secure an attractive variety and quantity of products_**

Our results of operations and profitability depend, to a considerable extent, on our ability to source and sell a
desirable and fresh mix of merchandise at attractive prices. We need to continuously source a sufficient variety
and quantity of merchandise from sought-after brands in a cost-effective manner. Our exclusive, invitation-only
membership model creates the opportunity for our suppliers to ensure that their overstock is sold in a discreet and
controlled environment, protecting their retail pricing strategies and the desirability of their brands while allowing
them to maximize value for their overstock. Our model allows us to clearly distinguish ourselves from other
fashion clearance channels such as online shopping clubs, factory outlet centers or other retail wholesalers and
has made us an attractive and preferred partner for many of our brands when they are seeking to clear overstock.
Our unique model facilitates our early access to high-quality inventory at favorable prices.

Developments in the retail fashion industry, combined with the seasonal nature of our suppliers’ industry, may
impact the timing of our merchandise procurement and the prices at which we can procure such merchandise. For
example, favorable economic conditions in the fashion industry typically lead to increases in production volumes
by our suppliers and, consequently, may result in greater availability of overstock merchandise in the market and
an opportunity to source such excess overstock merchandise at better prices. In contrast, extended periods of
financial uncertainty or decreases in consumer spending may cause our suppliers to reduce their production,
thereby limiting the amount of merchandise on the market and negatively affecting the prices at which we can
purchase overstock merchandise.

Sufficient availability of overstock in the market can be adversely affected by supply chain disruptions, changes
to the distribution plans of our brand partners or an overall decline in the fashion market. For example, the Russian
invasion of Ukraine in late February 2022 has and will potentially continue to have a wide range of supply chain
implications, including increases in cost and disruption in freight transport. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Related to_
_Our Business and Industry—Our business depends on our ability to continuously source and present a variety_
_and quantity of attractive products from various popular brands at attractive prices that will satisfy our_
_customers’ preferences and demands.”_

In addition, weather conditions can impact the timing and availability of merchandise. A mild autumn or a cold
spring may negatively impact the sale of winter and summer merchandise, respectively, by our suppliers. This
may lead to the earlier availability of merchandise but may also result in our need to lower prices to follow price
reductions by our suppliers online and in their high street retail locations. Also, changing and increasing volatile
weather conditions are creating unforeseen seasonal demand that cannot be fully covered with planned collections
or increased availability of overstock. We have the ability to purchase large quantities of merchandise, including
mixed lots, which are lots that do not contain a typical distribution of sizes and colors, increasing our value as
counterparty to our suppliers. As a result, we are often the first choice of our suppliers, reinforcing our customer
proposition by giving us preferential access to desirable merchandise.

For the year ended December 31, 2022, our cost of sales was 57.5% of our revenue and was influenced by
unfavorable overstock availability negatively impacting cost of sales, as well as a higher discounting environment,
leading us to increase our discount rate. For the year ended December 31, 2023, cost of sales was higher, at 57.8%
of our revenue, due to a highly competitive market environment leading to increased discount levels. For the three
months ended March 31, 2024, cost of sales was at 57.8% of our revenue, a 1.6 percentage points decrease
compared to the three months ended March 31, 2023, due to favorable overstock availability positively impacting
cost of materials.

**_Pricing_**

Our pricing strategy is to offer products to our customers at attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80% of the
recommended retail price. Some of the various factors which influence our pricing strategy are beyond our control,
including market conditions, overstock availability, and demand. For example, a competitive discounting
environment could influence consumers’ price expectations, which may in turn affect our pricing strategy, while
geopolitical uncertainty and price volatility could lead to a decrease in consumer confidence and spending.

Pricing of our products more broadly has a direct impact on our revenue and profitability margin. An effective
pricing strategy ensures optimal timing and pricing levels for a product as it moves through the different
markdown stages, thereby maximizing its revenue and profit contribution. Conversely, if we fail to manage our
pricing strategy adequately, we may lose sales and forfeit profitability. An effective markdown strategy improves
the quality of our inventory by ensuring efficient stock turnover. Continuous improvements of our pricing strategy
and our pricing-related technology, including a machine learning program for automatic pricing, have contributed

74


-----

to our revenue growth from the year ended December 31, 2021, to the twelve months ended March 31, 2024 and,
we believe, help us to maintain healthy Adjusted EBITDA Before Run Rate Cost Synergies Margins even in
challenging market conditions.

**_Fulfillment_**

Our fulfillment expenses, which are included in our selling and distribution expenses, comprise, among others,
costs related to content creation, warehousing, handling and packaging, shipping, payment, customer service and
returns. Our fulfillment expenses are driven by a number of factors, in particular the revenue share of our online
operations, the share of international shipping, the effectiveness of our fulfillment centers, capacity utilization, as
well as shipping and last-mile delivery costs for third-party carriers who handle the delivery of our products.

We primarily incur fulfillment expenses when we ship online orders from our fulfillment center. In the years
ended December 31, 2021, December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, we incurred fulfillment expenses of
€162.3 million (17.2% of our revenue), €188.9 million (18.0% of our revenue) and €221.5 million (18.1% of our
revenue), respectively. The movement in our fulfillment expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses to
revenue) in these periods was driven by the use of temporary fulfillment centers, inflationary costs associated with
investments in new fulfillment centers, higher shipping expenses due to a higher share of international business
and increased personnel expenses in logistics as a result of a higher business volume.

Fulfillment expenses are expected to increase as a result of growth in our business, but we expect this ratio to
improve in the coming years. While we expect to continue experiencing increases in our shipping costs per item
as a result of the growing international share of our business, we aim to offset these increases with a switch to
local last-mile carriers once we have reached sufficient scale in the respective country as well as through volume
discounts (despite price increases by some of our last-mile carriers). In addition, we expect to realize cost synergies
following the ramp-up of the new fulfillment center in Poland, combined with increased automation as well as
process optimization, to decrease our fulfillment expenses base per item.

**_New customer acquisition_**

Our closed membership model and our loyalty program – the VIP Program – are designed to trigger invitations
(and therefore viral new customer acquisition) by rewarding customers for successfully inviting other members.
New viral customers (customers who have been invited by existing customers) are the primary drivers of our yearon-year structural revenue growth and an important driver for our expansion. Our online business has grown at a
CAGR of over 20% from the year ended December 31, 2019, to the year ended December 31, 2023. Moreover,
viral customer growth is highly cost-efficient, with a low single-digit percentage of total revenue being spent
annually on viral engine-related expenses.

To complement our viral engine model, we introduced our new paid customer acquisition strategy during the
second quarter of 2021. Our paid marketing efforts allow us to invite potential new members to join our closed
membership model so that they can drive viral growth by using their invitation rights to invite new members,
accelerating our viral customer growth. Our paid marketing efforts are targeted towards specific customer
demographics and regions to drive our non-viral growth, especially in areas with currently lower penetration (such
as Northern Germany and our international markets). This “seeding” strategy is very effective with a highly
favorable marketing efficiency ratio (defined as incremental revenue generated from our paid marketing strategy
divided by marketing spend). Our paid marketing strategy has contributed 28% and 24% of our total increase in
new customers in the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, respectively. The customer base
we gain from our paid marketing strategy is supported by subsequent viral growth in the customer base, resulting
in strong marketing efficiency with €5.50 in average revenue per €1.00 in marketing spend from 2019 to 2023.
See “Our Business—Marketing—Paid customer acquisition.”

Our predominantly viral customer generation ensures high active customer growth with low marketing
investment. This has enabled us to keep our marketing costs structurally low. For example, for the three months
ended March 31, 2023 and 2024, we incurred an average marketing costs of 1.3% and 1.9% of revenue,
respectively. Our LTV/CAC ratio is defined as cumulative PCII per online customer since first order, actuals
(LTV). PCII is defined as gross margin minus fulfillment costs (incl. payments and customer care). CAC
(customer acquisition costs) is defined as total marketing expenses / total number of new customers. The following
graph reflects the LTV/CAC ratio for the 2019 and 2023 period and illustrates our ability to maintain short payback
periods on our marketing costs with steadily increasing trends:

The expenses we incur for our viral customer growth model, such as vouchers earned by customers for
successfully inviting other members, are reflected as sales deductions within revenue until December 31, 2022.
As of January 1, 2023, we are able to reasonably estimate the fair value of the vouchers earned by customers for
successfully inviting other members. Consequently, we capitalize the corresponding customer acquisition costs
as costs for obtaining a contract. The expenses of marketing activities, including our paid customer acquisition
strategy, are included in our selling and distribution expenses. In the years ended December 31, 2021,
December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, we incurred marketing expenses of €49.0 million, €20.3 million and
€21.1 million, respectively.

**_Payment Options_**

A variety of payment options is an important aspect of the shopping experience for our customers. We offer
different payment methods tailored to meet our members’ payment preferences, both in our offline retail stores
and our online platform, including credit cards, PayPal, direct debit, instant bank transfer and pay-by-invoice
(“buy-now-pay-later”). As part of our internationalization strategy, we are also focusing on making more local
payments methods available to our customers. Furthermore, we tailor our payment solutions by customer type and
offer certain payment options, such as pay-by-invoice, only to customers who have a sufficient purchase history
with us.

Customers’ choices of payment method can have a significant effect on our profitability. For example, revenue
can vary by up to 2% based on the payment methods available in Germany. In addition, certain payment options
can have better order economics than others, for example through lower return rates.

**_Investments in infrastructure_**

Our result of operations and cash flows are influenced by our investments in technology and fulfillment center
infrastructure.

Our business depends significantly on our ability to process transactions on secure information systems and to
store, retrieve, process and manage information. In the years ended December 31, 2021, December 31, 2022 and
December 31, 2023, we invested €24.2 million, €28.8 million and €33.3 million, respectively, and in the three
months ended March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2024, we invested €7.2 million and €9.6 million, respectively, in
technology-related capital expenditures mainly pertaining to the upgrade of our IT-system to strengthen our
technological capabilities and in-house excellence. Our primary front-office technology systems are used to
market products to end customers, to manage, track and deliver orders, and to monitor stock and interface with
suppliers and other business relations. We have invested significantly in the overall user-experience of our
customer-facing systems, as well as in marketing and analytics capabilities to boost customer acquisition, increase
sales conversion, and manage churn. We updated our online platform to support multiple currencies and to be

76


-----

available in multiple languages. We also expanded the platform’s payment capabilities to provide better and more
flexible options for different customer needs. In addition, we made investments in the scalability of the technology
architecture across systems and processes, to support future growth of the business and to manage orders more
efficiently. We have also invested in an upgrade of our IT systems.

We operate a modern fulfillment center in Poing, Germany, near Munich. The site, which was extended in 2019
and 2020, now has a footprint of 48,000 square meters and can hold approximately 10 million items of inventory.
The site also features multi-channel processes and also supplies our retail stores. We also operate a second largescale fulfillment center in Poland, which we began operating in the second quarter of 2023 with a footprint of
120,000 square meters. Lower wages in the Polish facility, as well as increasing automation over the next few
years, are expected to result in a lower operating expense per item.

**_Returns_**

Allowing our customers to easily receive, try on, and if required, return products free of charge is an important
part of our value proposition to our customers, contributing to customer satisfaction, supporting customer
conversion (from browsing to purchasing) and increasing customer lifetime value. A number of factors influence
our return rates, such as products not matching their online description, issues with product quality, unexpected
variations in sizes, or wrong items being shipped.

We continuously seek to optimize our return rates and minimize the costs associated with our free return policy
by focusing on the accuracy of our product descriptions, including size recommendations, and improving the
visualizations of our products on our apps and websites, avoiding returns where possible. Furthermore, we focus
on providing an efficient and reliable fulfillment process to make sure the right items are shipped and arrive in a
timely fashion.

In accordance with IFRS, we use our historical return rates to anticipate future returns and to deduct such
anticipated returns from our revenue and cost of materials. If actual return rates turn out to be higher, we lose the
corresponding share of revenue and profits. More than 99% of the products returned are recorded as inventory
and are available for sale again having undergone a quality assessment to ensure the return products are in good
order. We provision in our accounts for the expected loss margin from returns and less than 1% of return products
are damaged or otherwise not fit for sale.

**_Internationalization_**

We operate in the European online off-price fashion market for mid-market to luxury fashion, which currently
presents several highly attractive market dynamics to participants. Our unique proposition provides us with the
opportunity to continuously capture market share and participate in the structural growth momentum of our
market. Our approach to accelerate our international growth follows the following three stages: (1) create relevant
brand assortment, (2) localize the customer experience (with local language, website, payment methods, carrier
and customer care), improve shipment costs and invest in social media marketing, (3) drive predominantly viral
customer growth which in turn yields cyclical growth. We have successfully expanded our international business
in recent years, with the proportion of our revenue derived from our International segment steadily increasing,
and amounting to 28.4%, 34.0% and 39.9% of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2021,
December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, respectively, and 39.5% and 43.7% in the three months ended
March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2024, respectively. Our International segment revenue, which amounted to €267.5
million, €357.8 million and €489.2 million, in the years ended December 31, 2021, December 31, 2022 and
December 31, 2023, respectively, experienced a CAGR of 35.2% for the same period, compared to our Germany
segment revenue, which amounted to €675.4 million, €693.3 million and €736.8 million, in the years ended
December 31, 2021, December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, respectively, with a CAGR of 4.5% for the
same period.

**_Seasonality_**

Our business is seasonal, which is typical for retailers in the fashion industry. For example, we typically experience
an increase in sales in the fourth quarter of the year due to several special sales events (e.g., Black Friday sale,
Cyber Week sale and the Christmas shopping season). Following exceptional revenue growth due to the structural
shift towards online shopping due to the COVID-19 pandemic in the fourth quarter of 2021, we experienced a
normalization of our fourth quarter revenue in the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023, during
which revenue in the fourth quarter accounted for 32.6% and 33.0% of our total revenue for the year, respectively,
as a result of the readjustment of the online and offline retail sectors post COVID-19 pandemic. As a result of our

77


-----

seasonality of sales, any factors that harm our operating results during the fourth quarter of a year, including
unfavorable economic conditions or uncertainties caused by inflation and macroeconomic conditions affecting
consumer spending levels or inclement weather that deters customers from buying online or visiting our stores,
could have a disproportionate effect on our results of operations for the full year.

Our growth rate fluctuates from quarter to quarter, and we expect that it will continue to do so because of a variety
of factors, including the timing and success of our international marketing activities, the share of revenue driven
by promotional activities, seasonality and economic cycles that influence retail apparel purchase trends.

Furthermore, our pricing is influenced by the seasonality of our industry and the impact of weather patterns and
conditions. For example, if a fall/winter season is unusually warm, we may fail to sell some of the merchandise
for the season, resulting in pricing pressure on the same merchandise in the following fall/winter season.

In addition, our Operating Net Working Capital is affected by seasonal trading patterns. Our Operating Net
Working Capital typically reaches a peak from June to September, with a minimum position in January after the
Christmas season has passed.

**Key Items of the Consolidated Statement of Comprehensive Income**

Set forth below is a brief description of the key line items of our consolidated statement of comprehensive income:

**_Revenue_**

We generate our revenue primarily from the sale of fashion merchandise on our BestSecret online platform and
to a lesser extent from sales in our retail stores. Revenue is recognized upon delivery of the goods to the customer.
Revenue is recorded net of sales deductions, taxes and duties. For transactions with a statutory 14-day or longer
refund policy, we calculate the amount of the expected returns as of the reporting date based on historical return
rates under consideration of the actual returns until the date of preparing the consolidated financial statements.
We present the expected returns of goods on a gross basis and reduce revenue by the full number of sales that are
estimated to be returned. The sale of goods that is recorded in full upon delivery of the goods is then corrected by
the estimated number of returns. Vouchers earned by customers for successfully inviting other members represent
a payment to customers and therefore were reflected as a revenue reduction when redeemed by the customer until
December 31, 2022. As of January 1, 2023, we are able to reasonably estimate the fair value of the vouchers
earned by customers for successfully inviting other members. Consequently, we capitalize the corresponding
customer acquisition costs as costs for obtaining a contract. Revenue also includes revenue received from shipping
fees charged to customers when merchandise is purchased. In addition, we purchase some products, such as
jewelry, on a commission basis. In this case, we act as an agent, but are free in the setting of prices. Moreover, we
enable selected partners to sell goods directly to BestSecret’s closed customer community over our Curated
Platform. In both cases, revenue is earned in the amount of the commission received. Revenue is recognized within
our two operating segments, Germany and International.

**_Cost of Sales_**

Our cost of sales comprises primarily cost of goods sold, expenses for inbound logistics, allowances on inventories
and other costs in connection with sales. Cost of goods sold equals expenses for goods sold less discounts and
rebates granted by suppliers. Expenses for inbound logistics include all expenses incurred before the inventories
are stored in the fulfillment centers and consist mainly of customs and incoming goods transport expenses.
Allowances of inventories reflect write-downs of inventories to the net realizable value to account for risks from
reduced demand or quality of the goods. Other cost of sales also covers cost for the storage of goods and expenses
for depreciation.

**_Selling and Distribution Expenses_**

Our selling and distribution expenses comprise fulfillment expenses, sales expenses, and marketing expenses, as
well as amortization, depreciation and impairment expenses. Fulfillment expenses mainly consist of expenses for
outbound and return logistics including delivery costs and personnel costs associated with these processes. Sales
expenses primarily include payment costs and personnel expenses as well as incidental rental costs of the stores.

78


-----

**_Administrative Expenses_**

Our administrative expenses comprise general administrative expenses and technology expenses. Administrative
expenses largely consist of personnel expenses. The non-personnel costs primarily contain depreciation, licenses
for software and maintenance fees as well as consultancy fees and sundry general administrative expenses.

**_Other Operating Income_**

Our other operating income mainly comprises foreign exchange rate gains, income from affiliated companies,
income from reversal of provisions and accruals, compensations for damages, income relating to other periods,
and sundry other operating income. COVID-19 related lockdown revenue compensation is also recognized in
other operating income.

**_Other Operating Expenses_**

Other operating expenses mainly consist of foreign exchange rate losses, expenses for recharges by the parent
company, expenses relating to other periods, bad debt losses and sundry other operating expenses.

**_Financial Income_**

Our financial income includes valuation of embedded derivatives, income from exchange rate differences, credit
interest, interest income from affiliated companies, income from hedge ineffectiveness, subleases, tax refunds and
sundry interest income.

**_Financial Expenses_**

Our financial expenses primarily include interest expenses on the Existing Notes, interest expenses on any
drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility as well as commitment fees related to the availability of the
Revolving Credit Facility, interest expenses on lease liabilities, interest expenses on short-term liabilities, interest
expenses on liabilities from affiliated companies and interest expenses on hedge ineffectiveness.

**_Income Taxes_**

Our income taxes comprise current income taxes and deferred taxes.

million). Technology expenses decreased by €3.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to the
year ended December 31, 2022, which was mainly attributable to a higher share of capitalized personnel costs.
Compared to the year ended December 31, 2022, the general and administrative expenses increased by €1.1
million for the year ended December 31, 2023, due to general administrative expenses and service expenses with
Holdco partly offset by lower personnel expenses. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization
of intangible assets increased by €1.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, compared to the year ended
December 31, 2022 due to higher amortization of intangible assets as a result of our ongoing investments in tech
and data to further improve our IT systems.

_Other operating income_

Our other operating income increased by €3.1 million, or 64.6%, from €4.8 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022, to €7.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. Other operating income mainly
comprises income from foreign exchange rate gains, income from affiliated companies and reversal of provisions
and accruals.

_Other operating expenses_

Our other operating expenses increased by €0.7 million, or 11.1%, from €6.3 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022, to €7.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily due to
foreign exchange rate losses, expenses for recharges by the parent company and expenses related to other periods.

_Financial income_

Our financial income increased by €9.6 million from €6.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, to €16.4
million for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily due to valuation of embedded
derivatives, income from exchange rate differences, credit interest and interest income from affiliated companies.

_Financial expenses_

Our financial expenses increased by €22.4 million, or 57.1%, from €39.2 million for the year ended December 31,
2022, to €61.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, due to interest expenses in connection with the
Existing Notes and higher interest expenses on lease liabilities under IFRS 16 and short-term liabilities.

_Income taxes_

Our income taxes increased by €5.4 million from €2.4 million tax expense for the year ended December 31, 2022,
to €7.8 million tax expense for the year ended December 31, 2023, due to higher taxable income as a result of
increasing business volumes.

_Net income/(net loss) for the period_

Our net income for the period amounted to €2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to the
net income of €12.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2023, representing an increase of €10.2 million. The
increase in net income was attributable to the growth of our overall business in the year ended December 31, 2023.

_Revenue_

Our revenue increased by €108.1 million, or 11.5%, from €942.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021,
to €1,051.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Revenue growth was driven by the growth in the
number of active customers combined with robust order economics. The international segment drove this growth
with a revenue increase of €90.3 million, from €267.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to €357.8
million for the year ended December 31, 2022.

_Cost of sales_

Our cost of sales increased by €91.6 million, or 17.9%, from €512.6 million for the year ended December 31,
2021, to €604.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to increases in the
costs of materials as a result of the increased orders, partially offset by a decrease in depreciation of property,
plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets. Cost of sales as a percentage of revenue was 57.5% for
the year ended December 31, 2022, as compared to 54.4% for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase
was primarily due to overall business growth. Depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of

83


-----

intangible assets of €1.0 million (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €1.5 million) and personnel expenses of
€6.3 million (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €6.0 million) are reported in cost of sales for the year ended
December 31, 2022.

_Selling and distribution expenses_

Our selling and distribution expenses decreased by €4.9 million, or 1.5%, from €318.8 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021, to €313.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was mainly due to
decreases in marketing expenses and amortization and impairment of intangible assets partially offset by increased
fulfillment costs, sales expenses, and depreciation of property, plant and equipment. For the reasons described
above, selling and distribution expenses as a percentage of revenue decreased from 33.8% for the year ended
December 31, 2021, to 29.9% for the year ended December 31, 2022.

For the year ended December 31, 2022, our selling and distribution expenses consisted of fulfillment expenses of
€188.9 million (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €162.3 million), marketing expenses of €20.3 million (for
the year ended December 31, 2021: €49.0 million), sales expenses of €33.2 million (for the year ended December
31, for the year ended December 31, 2021: €28.9 million) and amortization, depreciation and impairment expenses
of €71.5 million (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €78.6 million). The fulfillment expenses increased by
€26.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to the year ended December 31, 2021 which was
mainly due to a higher share of international business and increased personnel expenses in logistics as a result of
higher international business volume. As a result, the fulfillment expenses ratio (the ratio of fulfillment expenses
to revenue) came to 18.0% in the year ended December 31, 2022 (for the year ended December 31, 2021: 17.2%).
In the year ended December 31, 2022, marketing expenses equaled 1.9% (for the year ended December 31, 2021:
5.2%) of our revenue. The decrease in marketing expenses was mainly due to increased efficiencies of the paid
customer acquisition activities. Compared to the year ended December 31, 2021, sales expenses increased by €4.3
million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was mainly attributable to an increase in costs for
payment service providers, which amounted to €14.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 (for the year
ended December 31, 2021: €12.8 million) and personnel expenses for the stores in the amount of €13.2 million in
the year ended December 31, 2022 (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €11.5 million), due to the fact that the
2021 figure was positively influenced by the receipt of government grants for short-term workers in our stores in
Germany and Austria during the COVID-19 pandemic. In the year ended December 31, 2022, amortization,
depreciation and impairment expenses decreased to €71.5 million (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €78.6
million), and primarily comprised amortization of brand names and customer base of €48.8 million (for the year
ended December 31, 2021: €58.7 million). This decrease was predominately due to the fact that the brand name
Schustermann & Borenstein was fully amortized in the year ended December 31, 2021.

_Administrative expenses_

Our administrative expenses increased by €15.3 million, or 19.3%, from €79.1 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021, to €94.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase of administrative
expenses was primarily driven by higher personnel expenses and technology expenses related to IT-licenses and
maintenance as well as higher consultancy fees. In the year ended December 31, 2022, our administrative expenses
consist of technology expenses of €27.9 million (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €21.3 million), general
and administrative expenses of €58.8 million (for the year ended December 31, 2021: €51.7 million) and
depreciation of property, plant and equipment and amortization of intangible assets of €7.7 million (for the year
ended December 31, 2021: €6.1 million).

_Other operating income_

Our other operating income increased by €2.0 million, or 71.4%, from €2.8 million for the year ended
December 31, 2021, to €4.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was mainly attributable
to income from foreign exchange rate gains, reversal of provisions and accruals, and income relating to other
periods.

_Other operating expenses_

Our other operating expenses increased by €2.7 million from €3.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021,
to €6.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was mainly attributable to increased foreign
exchange rate losses and other expenses in connection with a new fulfillment center, levies in lieu of employing
persons with severe disabilities and expenses for voluntary social benefits.

84


-----

_Financial income_

Our financial income increased by €6.8 million from €0.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, to €6.8
million for the year ended December 31, 2022 due to the positive change in fair value of the Existing Notes’
embedded derivative.

_Financial expenses_

Our financial expenses increased by €13.1 million, or 50.2%, from €26.1 million for the year ended December 31,
2021, to €39.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. Financial expenses mainly consisted of interest on
the Existing Notes and lease liabilities under IFRS 16.

_Income taxes_

Our income taxes increased by €0.8 million from €1.6 million tax expense for the year ended December 31, 2021,
to €2.4 million tax expense for the year ended December 31, 2022. This development is primarily due to a
decreased release of deferred tax liabilities in connection with a shortening of the useful life for the customer base
of “Schustermann & Borenstein” as a result of our rebranding.

_Net income/(net loss) for the year_

Our net income for the period amounted to €2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to net
income for the period of €3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, representing a decrease of €1.8
million. The decrease was attributable to a lower gross margin, higher fulfillment and administrative costs as well
as increased negative financial result, partly offset by lower marketing costs.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our main sources of liquidity are our net cash flows from operating activities and long-term financing, including
the Notes and the Revolving Credit Facility.

Our business model is focused on ensuring adequate liquidity to allow for flexibility with regard to the purchase
of merchandise, including opportunistic mixed lot purchases. Given our positive liquidity situation, we are able
to procure merchandise through our operating cash generation, providing us with flexibility which we believe
particularly appeals to our suppliers.

On July 14, 2022, we entered into the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, which will be amended and restated
by the RCF Amendment and Restatement Agreement which we expect to be entered into on or around the date of
this Offering Memorandum, totaling €110.0 million (of which €12.1 million thereof constitute guarantees
reducing the credit line). We expect the RCF Amendment and Restatement Agreement to become effective on the
Issue Date. The facility increased our flexibility with regard to the financing of our increased working capital
needs due to our growing business volume and the seasonality of the fashion business, as well as our growth
investments into a new fulfillment center and a notably improved tech and data structure.

Our ability to generate cash from our operations depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn
dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, regulatory and other factors,
many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors discussed in the section titled “Risk Factors.”

Although we believe that our expected net cash flows from operating activities, together with the borrowings that
will be available under the Notes and Revolving Credit Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity
and debt service needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient net cash flows from

**Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosures on Risk**

We are exposed to a number of risks arising from our normal business activities.

**_Market Risk_**

Market risk is the risk that the fair value or the future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because
of changes in market prices. Market risk comprises three types of risk: interest rate risk, currency risk and other
price risk, such as equity price risk.

The sensitivity analyses in the following sections relate to our position as of December 31, 2023. The sensitivity
analyses have been prepared on the basis that the amount of net liabilities, the ratio of fixed to floating interest
rates of the liabilities and the proportion of financial instruments in foreign currencies are all constant. The
analyses exclude the impact of movements in market variables on the carrying values of provisions, the nonfinancial assets and liabilities of foreign operations.

93


-----

_Interest Rate Risk_

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate because
of changes in market interest rates. As of December 31, 2023, the Existing Notes are affected by floating interest
rates.

Sensitivity of our earnings to a change in underlying interest rates by a rise of 100 basis points and a fall of 100
basis points on variable-rate loans and borrowings as well as on the present value of derivative financial
instruments and interest rate swaps are evaluated. Changes in the market interest rates of interest rate derivatives
have an impact on the financial result and are therefore taken into account in the sensitivity analysis.

We use derivatives to manage our interest risks. In January 2023, we entered into two hedging agreements to
mitigate its exposure to interest rate risks arising from the Existing Notes. We apply hedge accounting and
recognizes the effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivative instruments designated as cash flow
hedges in line item. Other comprehensive income, net of income taxes, and any ineffective portion is recognized
immediately in net income. Amounts accumulated in equity are reclassified into net income in the same periods
in which the hedged item affects net income. We intend to continue to leverage derivative instruments in
connection with the Notes.

The agreements of the hedging instruments were conducted on January 23, 2023 and January 25, 2023,
respectively, and have both the maturity date on January 15, 2026. The total nominal value is €200 million. The
hedging instruments are contracted to achieve a 1:1 hedge ratio on an economic basis to ensure an economic
relationship between hedging instruments and hedged items. For accounting purposes certain ineffectiveness may
result as the derivatives and the underlying are not totally consistent. The maturity date of the hedged item is on
July 15, 2027.

This implies that the major part of the hedged item’s duration has been hedged. Under the hedge agreements, we
receive variable rates of EURIBOR on each January 15, April 15, July 15 and October 15 and pay fixed rates of
interest of 3.066% and 3.089%, respectively, on the same periods.

We assess whether the derivative designated in each hedging relationship is expected to be and has been effective
in offsetting changes in cash flows of the hedged item using the hypothetical derivative method. The effectiveness
of the economic relationship between the hedged item and the hedging instrument are determined based on
maturities, interest rates and nominal amounts. The hypothetical derivative method is used to check whether the
designated derivatives effectively hedge the cash flows of the hedged items. In the hedge relationships, the main
sources of ineffectiveness are the credit risk of the counterparties and changes in the timing of the hedged highly
probable future transactions.

In the year ended December 31, 2023, cumulative effect from cash flow hedge of €1.1 million (in the year ended
December 31, 2022: nil) was recognized directly in equity. In the year ended December 31, 2023, a gain of €0.2
million (in the year ended December 31, 2022: nil) from hedge accounting ineffectiveness was recognized in the
result for the period, as the hedging relationship was not completely effective.

_Foreign Currency Risk_

Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value or future cash flows of an exposure will fluctuate because of
changes in foreign exchange rates. The effect from currency differences on the financial statements for the year
ended December 31, 2023, is mainly attributable to translation of certain lease liabilities and loans into our
functional currency. The exposure of this effect on the financial statements is expected to remain at this level.
Other than that, our exposure to the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates is insignificant.

94

**_Credit risk and risk concentration_**

Credit risk is the risk that a counterparty will not meet its obligations under a financial instrument or customer
contract, leading to a financial loss.

Concentration risks arising from the delivery of goods to major customers are subject to a special credit watch. In
the case of a return debit, we have implemented a dunning process operated by an external service provider. The
maximum exposure to credit risk of financial assets, without taking account of any collateral, is represented by
their carrying amount. We offer, under certain conditions, purchase on account. Due to the introduction of nonrecourse factoring, there is no exposure to credit risk as of December 31, 2023.

We are exposed to credit risk from our operating activities (primarily trade and other receivables, including
receivables from payment service providers not holding a banking license) and from our financing activities,
including deposits with banks and financial institutions. We do not hold collateral as security. There were no
significant credit risks or concentration of risk as of December 31, 2023.

_Financial instruments and cash deposits_

Credit risk from balances with banks and financial institutions is managed by our treasury department. Investments
of surplus funds are made only with approved counterparties, which have a long-term rating of at least “A-” by
S&P or “A3” by Moody’s. The restrictions are set to minimize the concentration of risks and therefore mitigate
financial loss through a counterparty’s potential failure to make payments.

**Liquidity risk**

We provide sufficient liquidity for each individual entity by cash pooling. Our objective is to maintain a balance
between continuity of funding and flexibility through the use of bank overdrafts and bank loans. We assessed the
concentration of risk with respect to refinancing its debt and concluded it to be low. We have access to a sufficient
variety of sources of funding and debt maturing within 12 months can be rolled over with existing lenders. We
have access to a sufficient variety of sources of funding with no major debt maturing before 2027. The Revolving
Credit Facility of €110 million was not utilized as of March 31, 2024.

We also participate in a supply chain financing arrangement with the principal purpose of facilitating efficient
payment processing of supplier invoices. Although there is a concentration of risk because payables previously
distributed among a high number of creditors are now concentrated in the financial institutions involved, the
liquidity risk from supply chain financing is deemed to be low as we diversified the relevant financial instruments
among different bank partners with an investment grade rating.
