**Strategy**

To build on our existing success, we have identified the following key elements of our strategy:

**_Expanding our footprint_**

Our strategic growth ambition hinges on expanding our presence, both in our core market, Germany, and
internationally. Although our business is subject to higher penetration in certain areas of Germany, we continue
to see opportunity for revenue growth within this market, which is supported by our almost 100% NMV retention,
robust customer loyalty and strong inflow of new customers. Furthermore, we recognize vast opportunities for
further international expansion. Our strategic approach to acceleration of international growth involves three steps:
(1) developing access to a relevant brand portfolio tailored to local customer preferences, (2) localizing the
customer experience by providing local language websites, payment methods, carriers and customer care,
improving shipment costs and investing in marketing, particularly social media, to generate new customers and
(3) as a final step, scaling our customer base and revenues through predominately viral growth.

**_Elevating our value proposition_**

Complementing our growth ambitions in the German and the International segments, is our luxury initiative,
which centers on enriching our portfolio with highly desirable luxury brands by forging direct relationships with
these brands. The launch of our luxury initiative in 2023 has had significant early success. As of the year ended
December 31, 2023, and since the launch of our Elevation Strategy, we have managed to win more than 20 leading
luxury and designer brands and our luxury fashion NMV experienced period-on-period growth in excess of 180%
for the three months ended March 31, 2024. Our luxury initiative is part of our overarching Elevation Strategy,

117


-----

which focuses on growing the share of highly desirable brands in our portfolio - both in the luxury and premium
segments. By winning new brands and by expanding our business with existing brands in these segments, we aim
to continue to make our assortment more appealing.

As part of our Elevation Strategy, we also enhanced our online presence by introducing a new high-end design
for our app and online shop and by adding a dedicated luxury section, thereby aligning more closely with the
appeal of luxury brands. We also established offices in the renowned fashion capitals of Paris and Milan,
underlining our commitment to expanding our ongoing international activities, and being closer to our
international brand partners. Our Elevation Strategy not only strengthens our relationships with highly desirable
premium and luxury suppliers, but also bolsters our appeal to our customers. By deepening customer relationships
through compelling offers, we continue to foster a strong community of loyal members. With our commitment to
enriching our product assortment, elevating our online platform, and refining our shopping and service
experiences, we promote the retention of existing and acquisition of new customers and pave a way forward in
the online off-price fashion market.

**Our History**

BestSecret draws on a heritage of 100 years in the textile industry. In 1924, Herman Schustermann founded a
textile company in Makredwitz, Germany and relocated to Munich in the late 1940s. In the early 1950s, Benno
Borenstein established his textile business in Munich. The two companies merged in 1960, and, after the death of
Herman Schustermann, a new cooperation was established with Herman’s son, Emil Schustermann, and Benno
Borenstein as partners. While Schustermann & Borenstein initially started as a combination of two textile trading
companies with regional customer bases around Munich, ready-to-wear clothes were added to the portfolio over
the next decades and the closed membership retail business model was born.

Prior to 2007, our business operations were limited to our Schustermann & Borenstein offline retail stores in
Munich. In 2007, we launched our BestSecret online platform. In 2011, we made the BestSecret online platform
available in the Austrian market, setting the first milestone for our international expansion strategy. Since then,
we have continued our online international expansion. Today, our multi-language online platform is available
across Europe with shipping available to 27 countries. We have continued to maintain a limited physical presence
with premium and outlet stores in strategic locations, with such locations designed primarily to support our online
platform.

In 2012, the BestSecret Group’s founding families sold a majority stake of 61% of the business to Ardian. In 2014,
construction commenced on the new centralized fulfillment center in Poing, Germany (near Munich), which
became operational in early 2016 and consolidated our then-existing seven warehouses. In 2014, we expanded
our offline retail footprint through the opening of a new store in Vienna, Austria. In 2016, we acquired Swiss
Online Shopping AG, a leading off-price player in Switzerland, to further expand our online presence in Germany,
Austria and Switzerland (hereafter referred to as the DACH region). In January 2017, funds owned and managed
by Permira acquired a majority stake in the Group. In 2019 and 2020, we expanded our fulfillment center in Poing,
Germany by approximately 60% to support our business growth.

In late 2020, Dr. Moritz Hahn joined us after nine years of experience at Zalando SE where he served as a member
of the Executive Committee and held numerous senior positions. He has since built a strong leadership team of ecommerce pioneers with decades of relevant experience across the tech and e-commerce industry, complemented
by senior individuals with long-term experience at and in-depth knowledge of the Company. In early 2021, this
senior leadership team announced a new strategy which is focused on online pure-play, profitable growth across
Europe. The offline strategy was sharpened to focus on supporting our online value proposition with premium
stores designed to elevate our brand image and outlet stores to clear inventory that fails to sell online. In 2021, the
structure and brand profile across the Group was simplified and harmonized, merging and renaming the companies
to solely feature the BestSecret name across the Group. In 2023, we launched our Elevation Strategy to grow the
share of highly desirable premium and luxury brands in our portfolio. We also enhanced our online presence by
introducing a new high-end design for our app and online shop and by adding a dedicated luxury section, thereby
aligning more closely with the appeal of luxury brands. In the same year, our new fulfillment center in Sulechów,
Poland, commenced its preliminary stage of operations. In 2024, we expanded our Sulechów fulfillment center
by 40,000 square meters to a total footprint of 120,000 square meters.

**Our Value Proposition**

Our business model offers a differentiated value proposition to brands and customers.

118


-----

**_Our Proposition to Brands_**

Our exclusive, invitation-only membership model enables brands to discreetly clear large volumes of overstock
in a high-end, desirable shopping environment entirely separate from their full-price channels. This protects their
brand equity, supports their sustainability goals and fosters our long-term and deep strategic partnerships.

Our value proposition to brands:

  - **Brand equity protection:** Through our invitation-only, closed membership model, information
regarding our brands and discounts is kept within the BestSecret online platform and is not made
externally available. With our unique closed membership online model, we provide brands the
opportunity to participate in the structural shift towards an online model with their off-price offering
while protecting their brand identity.

  - **Desirable environment: We focus on highly desirable brands to position brands next to peers on-site.**
Additionally, we provide a high-end shopping environment and access to an affluent and loyal customer
base.

  - **Clearance of large volumes: We support brands by clearing their overstock, thereby supporting their**
sustainability goals. Our stock-taking wholesale model (pursuant to which the inventory risk lies with
the Group) enables brands to efficiently and effectively clear overstock from their warehouses and,
combined with our pre-orders, creates revenue certainty. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis
_of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—_
_Marketplace” and “—Operations—Supply—Commercial models.”_ Our Curated Platform (online
marketplace model) gives brands the option to keep control over their inventory and engage with the endcustomer directly, while still utilizing our valuable member base and closed platform to discreetly clear
overstock.

**_Our Proposition to Customers_**

We are committed to providing our customers with exclusive prices across a wide range of clothing, shoes and
accessories from desirable brands, while maintaining a high-end shopping environment through our online
platform that is on par with leading online full-price platforms. With our unique proposition, dedicated customer
service, comprehensive VIP Program (as defined below) and exclusive partnerships, we reward and care for our
customers and seek to transform them into loyal members of our community.

Our value proposition to customers:

  - **Exclusive prices: Within our exclusive platform that is only accessible for members (by invitation only),**
we provide attractive discounts ranging from 20% to 80% on the recommended retail price.

  - **Superior brand portfolio: With a focus on premium and luxury brands, we provided customers with**
access to a highly attractive fashion assortment.

  - **Highly desirable environment and best-in-class customer experience: We strive to ensure a high-end**
seamless shopping experience for our customers that is on par with leading online full-price platforms.
We provide a highly integrated, user-friendly online experience with our online platform and app,
multiple payment options, efficient and fast fulfillment, shipment to 27 countries across Europe, easy
returns and excellent customer service. An important feature of our customer experience is our standing
offering, with no flash-sale campaigns or extensive delivery times.

**Operations**

To enhance our partnership with brands, we are committed to being a reliable and professional off-price partner.
With respect to our customers, we strive to ensure that shopping for off-price fashion on our online platform is as
convenient and enjoyable as possible throughout their entire journey. Therefore, the operational activities forming
the backbone of our online platform consist of the following business activities (and corresponding departments):
Supply, Demand, Convenience, Retail, and Technology and Data Foundation, which are described in further detail
below.

119


-----

**_Supply_**

_Brands and merchandise_

Our ability to build long-term relationships with our brand partners is key to ensuring that we have first access to
their stock lists. We have been able to retain business relationships with all of our top 50 brand partners from 2019
(excluding private label suppliers). With a focus on premium and luxury brands, we offer merchandise from a
sizeable number of brands. This has contributed to the breadth of our product portfolio and ensures that we are
not dependent on any particular brand partner or fashion trend. For the year ended December 31, 2023, our largest
brand partner accounted for approximately 4% of total NMV and our top ten brand partners, together, accounted
for less than 25% of our total NMV.

Due to the scale of our platform, we are able to purchase large volumes from our brand partners. We have
significantly increased our purchasing budget in-line with the strong growth in our business. At the same time,
management believes that our brand partners are reducing their number of total online off-price partners, and as
the leading online off-price platform in Germany by revenue, we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from
this market consolidation.

We actively manage our supplier base in order to continuously align with the assortment and volumes of
merchandise we require for our business. This enables us to maintain a fresh selection of merchandise year-round
– as of March 31, 2024, approximately 80% of our inventory value had been in stock for less than six months and
more than 95% for less than one year.

As part of our Elevation Strategy, we implemented sourcing initiatives that enable us to screen and add new brand
partners with a proven and systematic approach while allowing us to scale our biggest partners faster.

For the twelve months ended December 31, 2023, by product category, our total NMV comprised 30%
Womenswear, 23% Menswear, 17% Shoes, 13% Accessories, 8% Sports, 6% Kids and 3% Home and Beauty.

Our buying strategy combines overstock with in-season and end-of-season orders, as well as pre-season collection
orders, to allow us to offer seasonally relevant merchandise and a permanent assortment to our customers while
providing additional revenue to our brand partners. We supplement our merchandise from our brand partners with
our private label merchandise. Our merchandising teams support our buying teams in driving sales and
profitability by managing inventory investments and driving efficiencies in the purchasing process.

_Commercial models_

Because our product assortment is permanent and does not follow the flash-sale model of other off-price platforms
(in which a discount or promotion is offered by the off-price platform for a short period of time), we are able to
provide a broad selection of items to our customers at any time. As a result, our brand partners can sell their
overstock to us on the spot, without having to wait for a flash-sale window. See—“Risk Factors—Risks Related
_to Our Business and Industry-We source the majority of our merchandise on the basis of purchase orders with_
_our brand partners, and the lack of formal supply agreements could impact our ability to maintain these_
_relationships.”_

Thereby, we offer to cash-buy stock from brands under a wholesale model through which we sell the purchased
inventory. Consistent with customary practice in our industry, our wholesale relationships with many of our brand
partners are not based on formalized supply agreements but, rather, the regular submission of purchase orders or
price agreements renegotiated periodically between the parties on order forms.

Alternatively, brands can sell via our platform themselves, using our marketplace model, _BestSecret Curated_
_Platform, which we introduced in the year ended December 31, 2022. Through our Curated Platform, we offer_
third-party fashion brands the option to market their products on their own terms without us acquiring these
products first. Our Curated Platform enables us to collaborate with affordable luxury and luxury brands, which
tend to prefer marketplace models that give them more control over merchandise presentation and prices.
Furthermore, our _Curated Platform has increased our profitability through commissions with attractive_
economics, while having limited inventory and working capital impact. The warehousing and fulfillment typically
remain in the hands of third-party suppliers. Alternatively, suppliers are able to rely on us for fulfillment at their
option, which allows us to benefit from incremental fulfillment fees on Curated Platform sales.

120


-----

**_Demand_**

Our double-digit revenue growth over many years is driven by a combination of an average 100% NMV retention
of existing active online customers, combined with a consistently strong online active customer growth.

_Highly Engaged Customers_

Our desirable products, prices and service attract a customer base that is active, loyal and highly engaged. Driven
by our broad offering and incentivized by our attractive loyalty scheme, our customer base keeps spending with
us year after year, leading to strong retention rates. This means that NMV by customer cohort, grouped by year
of first purchase, typically stays stable in the following years. For example, in the year ended December 31, 2019,
we retained 98% of the online NMV from the prior year’s active customer cohorts. Similarly, in the year ended
December 31, 2020, we retained 97% of the online NMV from the prior year’s active customer cohorts, with the
subsequent three years achieving 119%, 90% and 97% retention for the respective customer cohorts. Over time
and across cohorts, we have an average NMV retention of almost 100%.

_Viral Customer Growth_

The majority of our customer growth stems from our viral customer growth, which is growth as a result of existing
customers inviting new members. In the year ended December 31, 2023, 76% of new active online customers
were viral new customers. To push our viral growth, we utilize a customer experience toolset that allows us to
collect meaningful data for behavioral key drivers and helps us understand the dynamics behind our viral engine,
enabling us to further drive viral growth. Our viral engine is tied into our membership system granting customers
a limited number of invitation rights that can be shared with friends and family. New invitees become members
and get access to our assortment of products and also receive a limited number of invitation rights after their first
purchase. Our viral model leads to exponential customer growth, as shown by our average of over 20 active
customers in the year ended December 31, 2023, stemming from a single customer that became active in 2009 (a
measure derived from all non-viral customers joining in 2009, including customers without invitation, counting
LTM customers only).

_Paid Customer Acquisition_

Beginning in 2021, we started complementing our viral customer growth by utilizing paid marketing efforts
pursuant to which we invite new potential members to join our closed membership model via one-on-one
marketing on social media platforms. These new customers can then in turn make use of their invitation rights to
invite new members, thereby accelerating our viral engine. Targeted social media advertisements drive our
customer growth, especially in areas with lower penetration (such as Northern Germany and international
markets). This “seeding” strategy has been implemented with scaled marketing expenses, while maintaining short
payback periods. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation—
_Key Factors Affecting our Results of Operations—New customer acquisition.”_

_Customer Loyalty Program_

Our customer loyalty program (which we refer to as the “VIP Program”) is designed to deepen our customer
relationships. The VIP Program includes three levels of status based on a point system: Silver (more than 300
points), Gold (more than 1,500 points) and Diamond (more than 2,500 points). Members collect points for each
online purchase, with each €1 spent (after returns) translating into one status point, as well as for recommending
new active customers and other activities (such as newsletter subscriptions or special sales events), which we
promote regularly. As of March 31, 2024, more than 70% of our customers have a VIP status. All Silver, Gold
and Diamond members receive vouchers for referrals of new active customers and receive a limited number of
invitations which they can extend to potential new customers. Depending on their status, our members receive
additional invitation vouchers, free priority shipping and sneak previews of new merchandise and benefit from an
extended free return period.

**_Convenience_**

_Content Management_

As an online fashion platform, our product content is key to helping our customers decide whether to order a
product or not, consequently driving sales and avoiding unwanted returns. Therefore, our content, both images
and text, needs to be accurate, inspiring yet realistic, complete yet relevant, and promote diversity to support our
ESG goals. Simultaneously, producing and/or onboarding of this content should be fast and cost-effective.

121


-----

Since we adopted our Elevation Strategy, we focus on continually enhancing our visual product content. For
example, we transitioned from virtual models to real models and increasingly incorporate brand images directly
from our brand partners. Luxury brands, in particular, prefer the use of their proprietary images on our platform
in order to tailor the presentation to their brand image. We outsource the creation of the majority of our content
to two specialized service providers that follow our content guidelines. Our internal team focuses on vendor
management, quality management and content innovations.

In addition to carefully crafting our visual content to guide and engage consumers, we also customize our product
selection to align with the unique preferences and tastes of each local market.

_Payments_

We offer different payment methods tailored to meet our members’ payment preferences, both in our stores and
online shop. These payment methods include credit cards, PayPal, direct debit, instant bank transfer and pay by
invoice. We believe that offering a wide array of payment methods enhances customer satisfaction and improves
our check-out conversion with respect to online sales.

_Logistics_

We operate two modern and large-scale fulfillment centers. One is located in Poing, near Munich, Germany, has
a footprint of 48,000 square meters and can hold approximately 10 million items of inventory.

In the year ended December 31, 2023, we launched a second fulfillment center in Sulechów, Poland. It has a
footprint of 120,000 square meters and is expected to nearly triple our existing storage capacity in Germany. Once
the center is fully ramped up over the next few years (including the development of automation capabilities), it is
expected to operate at a lower operating expense than our existing network.

Our logistics network also includes an externally operated returns processing center in Świebodzin, Poland, that
specializes in processing all returns; an externally operated Beauty and Bulk center in Slubice, Poland, that
specializes in the storage of bulky and beauty items, which commenced operations in June 2024; as well as two
smaller externally operated interim sites in Germany, until the Beauty and Bulk center is fully ramped up (expected
in the second half of 2024).

_Customer Care_

Our customer service team is available to help when a customer has a question or a problem. The customer service
team also strives to help us understand why our customers contact us in the first place and to ensure we address
the underlying root causes. We offer support through telephone, e-mail, and our self-help section on our website.
In addition to fast service with a high resolution rate for customer contacts, we focus on offering convenient
contact hours in our customers’ local language.

**_Retail_**

While we operate mostly online, our physical premium and outlet stores in Germany and Austria continue to be
an important part of our business model primarily to support and complement our online platform. In our premium
stores we offer a broad and attractive assortment of desirable brands in a high-quality environment, with products
typically arranged by key brands and presented, in some cases, in dedicated brand areas.

Our outlet stores serve as a sales channel for the overstock we are unable to sell profitably online, such as highreturn, single size or color articles and goods of second choice. This allows us to live up to our commitment to
conduct our business in an environmentally responsible and sustainable way by selling almost all of the
merchandise we receive from our brand partners within our ecosystem. Only items that are severely damaged and
cannot be worn anymore are not sold in our outlets, representing a negligible part of our stock.

Our offline retail store portfolio is comprised of four free-standing sites. Two sites are located in Munich,
Germany, one site is located in Dresden, Germany, and one site is located in Vienna, Austria. Most of our sites
are located on the periphery of the city center (i.e., off high street locations), which translates into higher sales
density, lower rent expenses and attractive cost-margin advantages.

**_Technology and Data Foundation_**

We are a technology and fashion company, continuously investing in the technology organization to support the
ongoing expansion of our online platform. Data is key to driving growth and, therefore, we have made substantial
investments to build a strong technology foundation that supports our future scale. Utilizing state-of-the-art, cloudbased data infrastructure, our key business data is easily accessible across all our business units to ensure faster,
more data-driven decision-making. Collaboration between data analysts, data scientists and data engineers further
ensures that the data we produce and analyze is put to its best use.

37% of our white-collar full-time employees, defined as non-warehouse or shop floor employees, work in our
three technology hubs in Germany, Spain and Greece as of March 31, 2024.

We aim to provide a user experience that aligns to that provided by leading full-price online platforms. We believe
we provide an exceptional experience on our apps with approximately 2.5 million downloads recorded in the year
ended December 31, 2023.

**Intellectual Property**

As of March 31, 2024, we owned or had the right to use 42 trademarks (including German, EU, Chinese, and

Additionally, in individual cases Best Secret GmbH enters into license agreements for word/figurative marks with

each party remains owner of any of its respective intellectual property rights included in its own existing
proprietary technologies, methods, or other existing intellectual property rights, while all new intellectual property

**Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) Matters**

According to TheRoundup.org, 87% of all textiles in the fashion industry end up on landfills, comprising 7% of
all waste in global landfill space (source: TheRoundup.org, 17 Most Worrying Textile Waste Statistics & Facts).
We believe our business model provides one of the most sustainable ways to shop for fashion. By focusing on
overstock clearance, we help ensure that nearly every piece of fashion that is fit-to-wear finds an owner, thereby
reducing the amount of fashion that is discarded as waste. In the year ended December 31, 2023, 76% of our total
intake was overstock merchandise. We give fashion its first life, just as second-hand retailers provide products
with a second life.

We support and complement our online platform with our physical premium and outlet stores in Germany and
Austria, which allow us to clear the overstock we are unable to sell profitably online anymore, such as high-return,
single size or color articles and goods of second choice.

We are working to ensure compliance with the growing body of regulations governing ESG matters and further
increase sustainability in what we sell and how we sell through our own Sustainability Program. As part of this
program, we strive to create a positive environmental and social impact and minimize negative impacts in this
regard. We also aim for our Sustainability Program to establish clear initiatives and transparent criteria against
which we measure our progress.

For example, in 2023, as a part of our sustainability initiatives and in an effort to reduce the number of discarded
fashion items, we expanded our online product take-back program by 50%, launched a pre-loved second-hand
product category and maintained the share of articles in our stock that could not be sold in our ecosystem at 1%.
Our targets for 2024 and the future include expanding our pre-loved product offering, as well as continuing our
product take-back programs.

Additionally, in 2023, in relation to improving the sustainability of our supply, we developed a sustainable
sourcing guide for textiles, conducted a workshop for buyers to train them on climate-friendly and sustainable
sourcing practices and increased the share of sustainable materials in our women’s fashion apparel line. Our goals
for the future include ensuring continued compliance with various ESG laws and regulations.

Further, as part of our commitment to ESG, we publish a sustainability report on an annual basis.

**_Our Governance and Management_**

We have created a governance structure to promote responsibility and accountability for ESG matters across the
Company. Furthermore, we have also implemented a meeting and alignment structure that we believe will allow

**Regulatory Environment**

We operate in several countries and our business is subject to various regulatory requirements under the laws of
the European Union (“EU”) and national laws in relevant countries. Laws and regulations applicable to our
operations may differ due to different national and local laws. Applicable regulatory requirements relate, in
particular, to our dealing with customers, consumer protection, and the processing of customer data.

By creating a common regulatory framework for the member states of the European Union (“EU Member
**States”), EU law reached a considerable degree of regulatory harmonization in several areas relevant for our**
business. EU law comprises both directives as well as regulations. While the latter apply directly in all EU Member
States, EU directives need to be transposed into national law in each EU Member State. Therefore, standards
contained in EU directives may slightly differ from one EU Member State to another depending on the actual
implementation into national law.

The following section provides a brief overview of selected EU and German legislation and regulations which are
applicable to our business. Similar laws and regulations also apply to our business in other jurisdictions in which
we operate.

**_Data Protection_**

The processing of personal data within the EU and the EEA is primarily governed by the General Data Protection
Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (Datenschutz-Grundverordnung, “GDPR”) which became effective on May 25, 2018.
The GDPR applies to any enterprise that is processing the personal data of individuals (data subjects) within the
EU/EEA regardless of its location and the data subjects’ citizenship or residence. It is also applicable where the
processing activities are related to (1) the offering of goods or services, irrespective of whether a payment of the
data subject is required, to such data subjects in the EU/EEA, or (2) the monitoring of data subject’s behavior as
far as their behavior takes place within the EU/EEA. The GDPR aims primarily to protect fundamental rights and
freedoms of natural persons and in particular their right to the protection of personal data and to harmonize the
EU regulatory framework of data protection.

Under the GDPR, personal data may only be processed for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and only if
the processing is covered by a legal basis (e.g., consent of the data subject, if it is necessary for the performance

126


-----

of a contract, to comply with a legal obligation, or if we rely on our overriding legitimate interests). Furthermore,
data subjects must be informed transparently before the processing of personal data about the circumstances of
the intended processing activities (e.g., purposes, retention periods, recipients of the personal data). This aims to
enable the data subjects to effectively exercise their rights under the GDPR (e.g., the right of access to or the right
to erasure of their personal data, if the relevant requirements are met). Furthermore, the GDPR provides restrictive
requirements as regards solely automated decision making and profiling activities, which could for example
impact marketing activities based on such processing of personal data.

The GDPR also stipulates that certain technical and organizational measures must be implemented to protect
personal data depending on the amount of and potential risk for the personal data processed. These measures may
include physical security against unauthorized access and manipulation, password security, reasonable encryption
as well as protection against accidental data loss, destruction, or damage. Based on the general accountability
principle of the GDPR, the processing activities and the corresponding data protection measures must be
sufficiently documented (such as keeping records of processing activities). Furthermore, under the GDPR, special
care and safeguards must also be taken when transferring personal data to countries outside the EEA to ensure
that a level of data protection equivalent to the EU is in place for the processing of personal data. Recent legal
developments in the EU, e.g., the ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union (“CJEU”) of July 16, 2020
(case no C-311/18, Data Protection Commissioner v Facebook Ireland Limited and Maximillian Schrems, socalled “Schrems II”) and the July 10, 2023, European Commission adequacy decision for the EU-US Data
Privacy Framework (“DPF”), have created complexity and uncertainty regarding such data transfers.

The GDPR provides for fines of up to €20.0 million or 4% of global turnover on a group basis, whichever is
greater and depending on the respective breach for non-compliance with GDPR provisions. Failure to comply
with the GDPR can also result in claims for compensation for financial or non-financial damages claimed by
individuals under Article 82 GDPR and cease and desist claims. Non-compliance may further result in
proceedings or actions against us by governmental authorities, including corresponding costs for litigation, or
require us to change our operations and/or cease or modify our use of certain personal data sets. We may also be
contractually required to indemnify and hold harmless third parties from the costs or consequences of
non-compliance with data protection requirements. Individual EU Member States, like Germany, also provide
criminal sanctions for specific severe violations. Finally, in addition to these regulatory risks, infringement of the
GDPR can lead to reputational risk and significantly undermine customers’ trust in our business.

In the event of a breach of the protection of personal data, we are required to submit data breach notifications to
the relevant local data protection authorities (“DPAs”) within 72 hours beginning with the awareness of a possible
breach. If the breach concerned entails a high risk to the rights of the data subjects, they also need to be informed.
Data subjects, DPAs and competitors, as well as consumer associations, and other authorized associations may
pursue claims, including potentially mass litigation, against us for breach of the GDPR.

We are subject to the supervision of the Bavarian State Office for Data Protection Supervision (Bayerisches
_Landesamt für Datenschutzaufsicht). To comply with regulatory requirements imposed on us, we have, inter alia,_
established a data protection organization as well as data protection processes, including, without limitation,
appointing data protection officers, where required, and have implemented data protection policies for all
employees dealing with personal data. However, the task of meeting all the data protection law requirements is
complex, in particular taking into account that there are still material legal uncertainties in various respects and
that data protection authorities continuously publish more detailed GDPR guidance.

In addition to the GDPR, the German Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, “BDSG”) applies
to the processing of personal data within Germany. The BDSG provides further data protection rules by making
use of derogation and opening clauses in the GDPR. It stipulates, inter alia, additional requirements to limitations
on the scope of data subjects’ rights and personal data processing in the employment context. Other EU Member
States implemented similar local data protection acts.

Furthermore, based on its data strategy, the European Union further revised the legal framework for the handling
data, for example through the Digital Markets Act and the Digital Services Act. Due to the novelty of the
regulations, there are still uncertainties as to its interpretation and implementation. Hence, we may not always
fully comply with the requirements of the Digital Services Act as interpreted by competent authorities and/courts.

**_Digital Services Law_**

Our business activities are also subject to the German Telecommunication and Digital Service Data Protection
Act (Telekommunikation-Digitale-Dienste-Datenschutz-Gesetz, “TDDDG”), which only recently replaced the

127


-----

former German Telecommunication and Telemedia Data Protection Act (Telekommunikation-Telemedien_Datenschutz-Gesetz). To the extent the TDDDG transposes the provisions of EU Directive 2002/58/EC on privacy_
and electronic communications (“ePrivacy Directive”), it prevails over the GDPR.

The TDDDG provides special data protection rules and also stipulates provisions on the use of cookies and similar
technologies, regardless of whether the data is personal data or not. Generally, the end user must actively consent
to the use of cookies and similar technologies on the basis of clear and comprehensive information, except for
cookies and similar technologies that are technically strictly essential for a service requested by the end user and
for cookies and similar technologies that are used exclusively for the transmission of messages via a public
telecommunications network. This is also in line with recent case law by the European Court of Justice and the
German Federal Court (Bundesgerichtshof), which have both specified the requirements on the use of cookies.
These provisions and rulings are relevant for our online business and the use of web tracking tools, each of which
relies on cookies and similar technologies, and must be taken into account by all website operators.

In addition, the TDDDG stipulates that we as a digital service provider must implement certain technical and
organizational measures in order to protect our customers’ data and our IT systems (e.g., protection against
unauthorized access and (technical) interference).

The Digital Services Act (Digitale-Dienste-Gesetz, “DDG”), which only recently replaced the former Telemedia
Act (Telemediengesetz), remains relevant to the extent information requirements are not superseded by either the
GDPR or the TDDDG. The DDG requires digital service providers to provide certain information on their website,
such as name and address and contact details (Section 5 DDG).

Non-compliance with the provisions on cookies and similar technologies under the TDDDG may result in
monetary fines of up to €300,000.

Moreover, the requirements for the use of cookies and similar technologies are constantly evolving. For example,
there is a draft Regulation of Privacy and Electronic Communications (“ePrivacy Regulation”) that would replace
the current ePrivacy Directive and national implementation laws, such as German implementation laws in the
TDDDG. While the text of the ePrivacy Regulation is still under development, data protection authorities’ recent
guidance is driving increased attention to cookies and similar technologies.

**_Consumer Protection Laws_**

We are affected by consumer protection laws that apply to businesses generally and, in particular, to businesses
that operate on the internet. At the EU level, consumer protection is comprehensively regulated by various
directives, inter alia:

  - Directive (EU) 2019/771 of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 20, 2019, on certain
aspects concerning contracts for the sale of goods (“EU **Sales of Goods Directive”);**

  - Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of October 25, 2011, as amended,
on consumer rights;

  - Directive 2005/29/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 11, 2005, as amended,
concerning unfair business-to-consumer commercial practices in the internal market;

  - Directive 2000/31/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of June 8, 2000, on certain legal
aspects of information society services, in particular electronic commerce, in the Internal Market
(“eCommerce Directive”);

  - Council Directive 93/13/EEC of April 5, 1993, as amended, on unfair terms in consumer contracts; and

  - Directive 98/6/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of February 16, 1998, as amended, on
consumer protection in the indication of the prices of products offered to customers.

With Directive (EU) 2019/2161 of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 27, 2019, as regards
the better enforcement and modernization of Union consumer protection rules, the EU amended the existing EU
instruments for strengthened consumer protection. EU Member States had to transpose the new rules in their
national laws by November 28, 2021, and must apply these new national laws since May 28, 2022.

128


-----

In Germany, for example, we are therefore subject to various laws concerning the protection of consumers, which
have been primarily laid down in the German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch). Pursuant to these laws, we
are responsible for the conformity of the shipped products with the agreed or implied quality at the time the
purchase is made. And a consumer has certain statutory warranty rights (irrespective of our fault) should a product
be defective at the time of delivery. If a product is defective, consumers may generally require the retailer to repair
or replace the product in question free of charge.

The German Civil Code also regulates distance selling contracts (Fernabsatzverträge) to protect consumer
interests. The consumer benefits, among other things, from a statutory right of withdrawal from a distance selling
contract within a period of 14 days after the consumer has received the respective goods and has been informed
about his right of withdrawal in a manner compliant with the statutory requirements. During this time, a purchase
may be cancelled without any specific reason. If the consumer has not been properly informed about his/her
statutory right of withdrawal, the respective right expires twelve months and 14 days after receipt of the goods. If
customers exercise their right of withdrawal, they must return the goods and the retailer must refund the purchase
price, including any shipping costs originally charged. However, the retailer is not obliged to reimburse consumers
for any additional costs if the consumer has expressly opted for a more expensive type of delivery (e.g., express
delivery). On the other hand, the consumer must usually bear the costs of returning the goods, unless the retailer
failed to inform him or her accordingly or the retailer has expressly agreed to bear these costs. The consumer also
has to compensate the retailer for any loss in value of the returned goods in case such loss is due to the consumer’s
handling of the goods in a way that was not necessary to examine its condition, features and functionalities of the
product and the retailer has informed the consumer accordingly.

With the substantial 2022 reform of German contract law (Schuldrechtsreform 2022), the German legislator has
introduced further consumer-friendly regulations based on the EU Sales of Goods Directive, e.g., the reversal of
the burden of proof regarding the defectiveness of the purchased item at the time of handover at the expense of
the retailer extended from six months to one year. The introduced amendments to the German Civil Code entered
into force on January 1, 2022.

The German Civil Code, in connection with the Introductory Law to the German Civil Code (Einführungsgesetz
_zum Bürgerlichen Gesetzbuch), also stipulates that certain mandatory information must be provided to the_
consumer, including material characteristics of the purchased goods, the identity of the seller, terms of payment,
delivery and/or service, price and payment details and the statutory right of withdrawal.

In addition, in accordance with the German Price Indication Regulation (Preisangabenverordnung), retailers must
ensure, among other things, that the price of each product is displayed clearly, precisely and legibly and shall be
accessible, legible and intelligible on websites.

Against the backdrop of Directive (EU) 2019/2161 as regards the better enforcement and modernization of Union
consumer protection rules, the German Price Indication Regulation has been amended to include, as of May 28,
2022, new regulations for the announcement of price reductions for goods. The overall aim is to make the original
price on which a price reduction is based more transparent to the consumer. To this effect, each announcement of
a price reduction also has to state the lowest price applied by the retailer within a period of 30 days prior to the
application of the price reduction. The aim is also to put a stop to short-term price increases in advance of price
reductions. Infringements of the Price Indication Obligation may constitute administrative offenses that can be
sanctioned with an administrative fine (Bußgeld) of up to €25,000. Price comparisons, including the comparison
of actual price versus the recommended retail price as we carry them out, do not fall under the scope of the
directive.

We are also subject to rules and regulations relating to unfair competition in the jurisdictions in which we operate.
In particular, in Germany, competitors, consumer associations (Verbraucherverbände) and other authorized
associations may seek to enforce alleged violations of, or the failure to comply with, the Act Against Unfair
Competition (Gesetz gegen den unlauteren Wettbewerb). Based on the Act Against Unfair Competition, unfair
commercial practices are illegal. Unfair commercial practices include, inter alia, commercial practices which are
misleading (including untrue information as to the existence of a special price advantage, the price or the manner
in which it is calculated), which constitute an unreasonable nuisance, which make use of harassment, coercion, or
undue influence, as well as unsolicited marketing (including unsolicited e-mail marketing).

Additionally, we must comply with information requirements relating to the European Online Dispute Resolution
(“ODR”) platform for consumers. On January 9, 2016, Regulation (EU) 524/2013 of the European Parliament
and of the Council of May 21, 2013, on online dispute resolution for consumer disputes (“ODR Regulation”)
entered into force. It requires online retailers to disclose certain information on their websites to ensure that

129


-----

consumers are aware of the new ODR possibilities. Another information requirement is set up by Directive
2013/11/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of May 21, 2013, on alternative dispute resolution for
consumer disputes (“ADR-Directive”). In Germany, for instance, the implementation act, the Consumer Dispute
Resolution Act (Verbraucherstreitbeilegungsgesetz) generally obliges online retailers to inform their customers
to what extent they are willing or obliged to participate in alternative dispute resolution procedures. Anyone who
has undertaken or is obliged to participate in dispute resolution proceedings must provide information on the
address and website of the competent alternative dispute resolution body.

**_Foreign Trade and Customs Law_**

We source many of our products within the European Union. Within the European internal market, the principle
of free movement of goods, as stipulated in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, applies. With
respect to import and export of goods from countries which are not members of the EU, we must comply with
national and European foreign trade and customs regulations. At the EU level our relevant regulatory framework
is based on the Union Customs Code (Regulation (EU) 952/2013). In Germany, the Foreign Trade and Payments
Act (Außenwirtschaftsgesetz) and the Ordinance on the Foreign Trade and Payments Act

(Außenwirtschaftsverordnung) constitute additional regulations which, _inter alia, set forth rules of procedure._
Infringements of customs or foreign trade regulations may be sanctioned with an administrative fine (Bußgeld) if
categorized as administrative offenses or with a fine (Geldstrafe) or custodial sentence (Freiheitsstrafe) if
categorized as criminal acts. Depending on the extent and nature of the underlying administrative offense, the
respective fine may amount to up to €30,000 for violations of procedural regulations and up to €500,000 for
violations of other regulations of the Foreign Trade and Payments Act and even higher in certain administrative
offenses. Even higher fines are possible in case of skimming of profits (Gewinnabschöpfung). The authorities may
from time to time undertake external audits (Außenwirtschaftsprüfung) to assess whether we have complied with
the regulations of the Foreign Trade and Payments Act and the pertaining ordinances.

Whereas imports and exports within the EEA are in principle not liable to customs duty, the movement of goods
beyond the frontiers of the EEA may be subject to customs. The customs control charges, _inter alia, statutory_
import duties (Einfuhrabgaben). Customs offices may, from time to time initiate customs inspections
(Zollprüfung) to assess whether customs regulations have been infringed.

The countries belonging to the EEA may charge customs duties if products are exported into such non-EEA
countries. We also distribute our products in Switzerland (which does not belong to the EEA). Switzerland,
however, is party to a preferential agreement (Präferenzabkommen), such agreements being concluded with the
European Union and certain other countries in order to facilitate the exchange of goods. The rate of customs duty
for goods exported into countries which are parties to the preferential agreement is considerably lower than the
regular customs duty rate. The customs administration assesses in a preference inspection (Präferenzprüfung) in
accordance with the Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2015/2447, as amended, which applies from
May 1, 2016, whether the requirements and conditions set forth in the preferential agreement are complied with.

Following the beginning of the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, businesses involving Russia and Belarus as
well as regions of the Ukraine are subject to statutory sanctions (including Council Regulation (EU) No 833/2014
of 31 July 2014, Council Regulation (EC) No 765/2006 of 18 May 2006 and Council Regulation (EU) No
269/2014 of 17 March 2014). We continuously assess the impact of changes in the geopolitical situation of our
business and take steps to ensure compliance with developing sanctions and export controls. We are further
required to comply with financial and trade sanctions against embargoed countries, sectoral sanctions (which, for
example, target certain sectors of the Russian economy) and list-based sanctions against certain entities and
individuals, including persons identified on the US Department of the Treasury’s Office of Foreign Asset Control
(“OFAC”) List of Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons (the “SDN List”). As a general matter,
US sanctions prohibit only US persons from transacting or dealing with parties on the SDN List, absent OFAC
authorization. The obligation to screen US sanctions lists may follow from contracts with suppliers, credit
facilities, or loan agreements that require compliance with US sanctions or screening against US sanctions lists.

**_Product Liability and Textile Labeling Law_**

In Germany, in addition to the general liability under civil law, we are in general subject to liability under the
Product Liability Act (Produkthaftungsgesetz) which is based on Council Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25, 1985,
on the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the EU Member States concerning
liability for defective products. Under this act, we are liable, regardless of fault, for damage to life, body, health
and property caused by defective products to the extent we qualify as the “manufacturer” under the Product
Liability Act. This may be the case if we actually manufacture the products but also if we place our own logo or

130


-----

name on the products or if we import the products into the EEA. The producer`s liability is limited to an amount
of €85 million. In case of any damage to property, the injured party has to pay for damages up to an amount of
€500.

Furthermore, although there is no coherent legal framework for trade in textiles in Germany, certain laws and
regulations may apply to us. For example, the German Food, Consumer Goods and Feed Act (Lebensmittel-,
_Bedarfsgegenstände- und Futtermittelgesetzbuch) and the German Ordinance on Consumer Goods_
(Bedarfsgegenständeverordnung) include special regulations which aim at preventing possible damage to human
health caused by textiles, especially due to toxic substances or contamination. Similarly, the German Chemicals
Prohibition Ordinance (Chemikalien-Verbotsverordnung) prohibits the placing on the market of certain substances
and preparations as well as products containing such substances or preparations as listed in detail therein.
Furthermore, textiles may only be made available on the German market if they comply with the German Product
Safety Act (Produktsicherheitsgesetz) which is based on Directive 2001/95/EC of the European Parliament and
of the Council of December 3, 2001 on general product safety (“Product Safety Directive”) and complements
the EU regulations on market surveillance and compliance of products (Regulation (EC) 765/2008 of the European
Parliament and of the Council of July 9, 2008, as amended, setting out the requirements for accreditation and
market surveillance relating to the marketing of products and Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 of the European
Parliament and of the Council of June 20, 2019 on market surveillance and compliance of products). Under
German jurisdiction, this regulation is accompanied by the Market Surveillance Act (Marktüberwachungsgesetz)
which came into force on July 6, 2021.

These provisions on product safety apply to a wide variety of non-food products, including clothing and footwear
and are applicable to both the e-commerce and physical stores. They oblige retailers to ensure that their products
comply with applicable safety requirements. Moreover, a retailer is generally required to participate in the
monitoring of the safety of its products. Infringements of product safety regulations may be sanctioned with fines
and in severe cases with criminal sanctions.

We are further subject to the Regulation (EU) 1007/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of
27 September 2011 on textile fiber names and related labelling and marking of the fiber composition of textile
product pursuant to which textiles may only be made available on the European market if they are labeled or
marked with certain information, in particular regarding textile fibers. Depending on the implementing laws of
the EU member states, infringements of the textile labeling requirements may constitute administrative offenses.
In Germany the Regulation is supplemented by the Act on Textile Labeling (Textilkennzeichnungsgesetz). This
law creates the necessary conditions for effective enforcement of the Regulation (EU) 1007/2011 and, in
particular, lays down regulations on the powers of the authorities involved in market surveillance and on
administrative offences. Administrative offenses may be sanctioned with a fine of up to €10,000. Moreover,
violations of the provisions may be considered as unfair trade practices which are prohibited under the German
Act Against Unfair Competition (Gesetz gegen den unlauteren Wettbewerb). As regards sold footwear, Directive
94/11/EC of European Parliament and Council of 23 March 1994, as amended, on the approximation of the laws,
regulations and administrative provisions of the EU Member States relating to labelling of the materials used in
the main components of footwear for sale to the consumer is applicable. The German legislator transposed the
directive into national law by means of the German Ordinance on Consumer Goods which contains regulations
concerning the content and form of footwear labeling.

**_Regulations on Packaging and Waste_**

We are subject to statutory provisions regarding waste management and packaging. Directive 2008/98/EC of the
European Parliament and of the Council of November 19, 2008 on waste (European Waste Framework Directive),
as amended, provides for the legislative basis of a recycling society in the EU. Its provisions on the collection,
transport, recovery and disposal of waste requires the EU Member States to take appropriate measures for
prevention of waste as a matter of priority and to ensure that waste is recovered or disposed of without endangering
human health or causing harm to the environment. In Germany, the main waste disposal provisions are set forth
in the Waste Management Act (Kreislaufwirtschaftsgesetz) which is supplemented and concretized by a number
of regulations.

Online retailers are subject to regulations on packaging. Directive 94/62/EC on packaging and packaging waste
and its German implementation law, the Packaging Act (Verpackungsgesetz) aim to reduce the impact of
packaging waste on the environment. To this end, various obligations are imposed on the manufacturers and
retailers. The German Packaging Act requires both to participate in a disposal and recycling system and imposes
certain takeback obligations. Typically, these requirements are complied with by registering one’s activities in the
German waste packaging register and paying a license fee based on the amount of packaging waste put into

131


-----

circulation. In general, online retailers are only responsible for the shipping packaging. When importing products,
however, the retailer may also be responsible for sales packaging. Infringements of these regulations may be
sanctioned by administrative fines of up to €200,000.

**_Regulations on Cyber Security_**

We are also subject to regulations on cybersecurity. The GDPR and national laws like the German BDSG and
TDDDG require us to implement certain technical and organizational measures to protect our customers’ data and
IT systems. These measures may include physical security against unauthorized access and manipulation,
password security, reasonable encryption as well as protection against accidental data loss, destruction, or damage.
In case of a personal data breach, we are obliged to notify the breach to the competent data protection authority
within 72 hours after having become aware of it, unless the personal data breach is unlikely to result in a risk to
the rights and freedoms of natural persons. When the personal data breach is likely to result in a high risk to the
rights and freedoms of natural persons, we are also required to communicate the personal data breach to the
affected data subject without undue delay.

**_Regulations on Payment Process_**

Directive (EU) 2015/2366 of the European Parliament and of the Council of November 25, 2015 on payment
services in the internal market, among others, covers online-based payment services, provides for a uniform
regulation of payments via internet and mobile phones and increased customer protection and requirements for
user authentication, such as two-factor authentication. The German legislator has adopted the Law on the
transposition of Payment Services Directive Two (Gesetz zur Umsetzung der Zweiten Zahlungsdiensterichtlinie)
which mainly amended the German Payment Services Supervision Act (Zahlungsdiensteaufsichtsgesetz) and the
German Civil Code (Bürgerliches Gesetzbuch).

**_Supply Chain Duty of Care Act and CSDDD_**

On January 1, 2023, the German Supply Chain Duty of Care Act (Lieferkettensorgfaltspflichtengesetz¸ “Supply
**Chain Duty of Care Act”) became generally effective. The legislation requires affected companies to conduct**
adequate due diligence throughout their supply chains in relation to human rights and (certain) environmental
risks. This includes conducting a risk analysis, establishing internal responsibilities for human rights and
environmental protection, comprehensive preventative measures, and grievance mechanisms. Additionally,
companies concerned are obliged to continuously document the fulfillment of due diligence obligations and to
keep records in this respect for at least seven years. In an annual report, which must be published on the company’s
website and submitted electronically to the competent authority, companies must report on their adherence to due
diligence obligations. The report needs to be submitted no later than four months after the end of the business
year. Infringements of these regulations may be sanctioned by administrative fines of up to €800,000 or, in the
case of legal entities with an average annual worldwide turnover above €400 million, up to 2% of the average
annual worldwide turnover. Since January 1, 2024, companies in Germany with generally at least 1,000 employees
are within the scope of application of the Supply Chain Duty of Care Act. In connection with this legislation, we
have implemented a risk management system designed to address human rights issues and environmental risks as
required under the Supply Chain Duty of Care Act. As part of this system, we have, among other steps,
implemented a supplier code of conduct governing supplier requirements and other preventative measures, such
as trainings.

On May 24, 2024, the Council of the European Union has formally approved the Corporate Sustainability Due
Diligence Directive (“CSDDD”), following the adoption by the European Parliament on April 24, 2024. It is
expected that the CSDDD will become effective by mid-2024 and incorporated into German law by mid-2026.
The directive aims at providing a harmonized legal framework for sustainability considerations in the supply chain
of European companies. Among other things, it will establish a corporate due diligence duty, which is aimed at
ending, preventing, mitigating, and accounting for negative human rights and environmental impacts in a
company’s own operations, including subsidiaries, and their value chains. Upon its full rollout five years after
entry into force, the CSDDD will apply to companies that have over 1,000 employees and a net worldwide
turnover above €450 million. The German Supply Chain Duty of Care Act is expected to be adapted accordingly,
as based on the implementation of the CSDDD. Due to the threshold included in the CSDDD, it is likely that the
new provision will not be applicable to us until 2028 or, if we have not reached 3,000 employees by then, 2029.

**Revolving Credit Facility Agreement**

**_Overview and structure_**

On July 14, 2022, the Issuer (as an original borrower and an original guarantor), Holdco (as midco), Best Secret
GmbH (as an original borrower and an original guarantor), Best Secret Logistik GmbH (as an original guarantor),
Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft, Goldman Sachs Bank Europe SE, JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., London
Branch and UniCredit Bank GmbH (as original lenders), UniCredit Bank GmbH (as facility agent) and UniCredit
Bank GmbH (as security agent) (amongst others) entered into a revolving credit facility agreement (the “Original
**Revolving Credit Facility Agreement”). On or about the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Original**
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement will be amended and restated by the RCF Amendment and Restatement
Agreement. We expect the RCF Amendment and Restatement Agreement to become effective on the Issue Date.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement provides for borrowings of up to €110.0 million on a committed basis.
The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower under the Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement in euro, Swiss francs, sterling or certain other currencies (if agreed) by the drawing of cash
advances, the issue of Letters of Credit (the “Letters of Credit”) (upon the appointment of an issuing bank) and
by way of any Ancillary Facilities that may be made available thereunder (each as defined in the Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement). Subject to certain exceptions, loans may be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time.
Borrowings are available, amongst other things, to be used for general corporate and working capital purposes of
the Group (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) including, without limitation, for payment of
interest under the Notes.

In addition, the Issuer may elect to request additional facilities either as a new facility or as additional tranches or
increase of an existing facility (including any previously incurred additional facility) under the Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement (the “Additional Facility Commitments”) in amounts up to the Credit Facilities Basket (as
defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) or, to the extent it is exceeded, would otherwise constitute
Permitted Debt (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). The Issuer and the lenders may agree to
certain terms in relation to the Additional Facility Commitments, including the margin, the maturity date and the
availability period (each subject to parameters as set out in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). There are
certain limitations (including as to maximum amount) on the ability to incur Additional Facility Commitments.

**_Availability_**

The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized until the date falling one month prior to the maturity date of the
Revolving Credit Facility.

**_Borrowers and Guarantors_**

The Issuer is an original borrower and an original guarantor under the Revolving Credit Facility. A mechanism is
included in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to enable certain of the Issuer’s subsidiaries to accede as
additional borrowers or additional guarantors under the Revolving Credit Facility, subject to certain conditions.
The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also requires that, subject to, for the avoidance of doubt, the
section entitled “Guarantees” below, in the future each member of the Group (as defined in the Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement) which is or becomes a Material Company (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement), or is otherwise required to become a guarantor in order to satisfy the Guarantor Coverage Test (as
defined below), becomes an additional guarantor under the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and, where
applicable, shall grant security over certain of its material assets in favor of the Security Agent (subject to agreed
security principles included in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (the “Agreed Security Principles”)).

137


-----

**_Maturity and Repayment Requirements_**

The Revolving Credit Facility matures on the date falling 54 months after the 2024 Effective Date (as defined in
the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). Each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period
relating thereto, subject to a netting mechanism against amounts to be drawn on such date. All outstanding
amounts under the Revolving Credit Facility must be repaid in full on or prior to the maturity date for the
Revolving Credit Facility. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility
may be re-borrowed during its availability period, subject to certain conditions. The maturity date for a facility
under an Additional Facility Commitment is the date agreed between the Issuer and the relevant lenders.

**_Interest Rate and Fees_**

Loans under the Revolving Credit Facility will bear interest at rates per annum equal to EURIBOR (in respect of
loans denominated in euro), SONIA (in respect of loans denominated in sterling) or SARON (in respect of loans
denominated in Swiss francs) plus, in each case, an initial margin of 3.25% per annum. The applicable margin in
respect of the Revolving Credit Facility shall be calculated in accordance with a margin ratchet (subject to
customary conditions).

A commitment fee is payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility
at a rate of 30% of the then applicable margin. The commitment fee is payable quarterly in arrear on (i) either (at
the Issuer’s sole and absolute discretion) the last day of each successive period of three Months which ends during
the availability period or each quarter date occurring during the availability period (subject to certain notification
requirements); (ii) the last day of the availability period of the Revolving Credit Facility; and (iii) if cancelled, on
the cancelled amount of the relevant lender’s commitment under the Revolving Credit Facility at the time such
cancellation is effective.

Default interest on overdue amounts is calculated at a rate which is 1% higher than that rate applicable to the loans
under the Revolving Credit Facility.

The Issuer is also required to pay customary agency fees to the Facility Agent and the Security Agent in connection
with the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

**_Guarantees_**

The Issuer, Best Secret GmbH and Best Secret Logistik GmbH have provided a senior guarantee of all amounts
payable to each Finance Party (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) by them or any of the
Issuer’s subsidiaries which accede to the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement as additional borrowers or
additional guarantors.

The Revolving Credit Facility Agreement requires that (subject to the Agreed Security Principles) each subsidiary
of the Issuer that is or becomes a Material Company (which definition includes, among other things, any whollyowned member of the Group (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) incorporated in a Guarantor
Jurisdiction (as defined below) and that has earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization
representing more than 5% of Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement),
subject to certain exceptions)) will be required to become an additional guarantor under the Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement within 180 days of the last date (including any applicable extension or grace period) (or such
later date as the Facility Agent may agree) on which the applicable annual financial statements for the relevant
fiscal year demonstrating that such subsidiary is a Material Company were required to be delivered.

Furthermore, if on the last day of a fiscal year of the Issuer, the aggregate EBITDA of the guarantors under the
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement represents less than 80% of the aggregate EBITDA of wholly-owned
members of the Group (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) incorporated in a Guarantor
Jurisdiction (as defined below) (on a consolidated basis and excluding the EBITDA of any on-balance sheet joint
ventures and any member of the Group (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) that is not required
to or cannot become a guarantor due to legal prohibitions or the Agreed Security Principles) (subject to certain
exceptions) (the “Guarantor Coverage Test”) the Issuer must, within 180 days of the last date (including any
applicable extension or grace period) (or such later date as the Facility Agent may agree) on which the applicable
annual financial statements for the relevant year were required to be delivered, cause sufficient members of the
Group (as defined in the Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) to accede to the Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement as additional guarantors (subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain exceptions) to satisfy
the Guarantor Coverage Test (to be calculated as if such additional guarantors had been guarantors on such last
day of the relevant fiscal year).
